(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span>2011); <sup>(<em>c</em>)</sup> from Omont et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span>2013); <sup>(<em>d</em>)</sup> from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span>D14; <sup>(<em>e</em>)</sup> from Frayer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span>2011, table\u00a01, assuming a 30 per cent error) and Lupu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span>2012, table\u00a04, assuming a 30 per cent error); \u2020 \u2018tentative\u2019.</p></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA; Sutherland\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-affilitation\">\r\n        <div class=\"aff\"><span class=\"label\">8</span>School of Mathematical Sciences, Queen Mary, University of London, Mile End Road, London E1 4NS, UK</div>\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-search-label\">\r\n        Search for other works by this author on:\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n<div class=\"info-card-search info-card-search-internal\">\r\n    <a href=\"/mnras/search-results?f_Authors=W.+Sutherland\">Oxford Academic</a>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-search info-card-search-google\">\r\n        <a href=\"http://scholar.google.com/scholar?q=author:%22Sutherland W.%22\">Google Scholar</a>\r\n    </div>\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-search info-card-search-ads\">\r\n        <a href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/nph-abs_connect?return_req=no_params&amp;author=Sutherland,W\">ADS</a>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>                                            </span>\r\n                                        </span>\r\n                                        <span class=\"al-author-name-more js-flyout-wrap\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                                            <a class=\"linked-name\" href=\"javascript:;\">P. Temi</a><span class='delimiter'>, </span>\r\n\r\n                                            <span class=\"al-author-info-wrap arrow-up\">\r\n<div id=\"authorInfo_OUP_ArticleTop_Info_Widget\" class=\"info-card-author authorInfo_OUP_ArticleTop_Info_Widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"name-role-wrap\">\r\n        <div class=\"info-card-name\">\r\n    P. Temi\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-affilitation\">\r\n        <div class=\"aff\"><span class=\"label\">29</span>Astrophysics Branch, NASA/Ames Research Center, MS 245-6, Moffett Field, CA 94035, USA</div>\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-search-label\">\r\n        Search for other works by this author on:\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n<div class=\"info-card-search info-card-search-internal\">\r\n    <a href=\"/mnras/search-results?f_Authors=P.+Temi\">Oxford Academic</a>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-search info-card-search-google\">\r\n        <a href=\"http://scholar.google.com/scholar?q=author:%22Temi P.%22\">Google Scholar</a>\r\n    </div>\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-search info-card-search-ads\">\r\n        <a href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/nph-abs_connect?return_req=no_params&amp;author=Temi,P\">ADS</a>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>                                            </span>\r\n                                        </span>\r\n                                        <span class=\"al-author-name-more js-flyout-wrap\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                                            <a class=\"linked-name\" href=\"javascript:;\">J. Wardlow</a><span class='delimiter'></span>\r\n\r\n                                            <span class=\"al-author-info-wrap arrow-up\">\r\n<div id=\"authorInfo_OUP_ArticleTop_Info_Widget\" class=\"info-card-author authorInfo_OUP_ArticleTop_Info_Widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"name-role-wrap\">\r\n        <div class=\"info-card-name\">\r\n    J. Wardlow\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-affilitation\">\r\n        <div class=\"aff\"><span class=\"label\">11</span>Department of Physics &amp; Astronomy, University of California, Irvine, CA 92697, USA</div>\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-search-label\">\r\n        Search for other works by this author on:\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n<div     </div>\r\n<div class=\"pub-history-wrap clearfix\">\r\n\r\n        <div class=\"pub-history-row clearfix\">\r\n            <div class=\"ww-citation-primary\"><em>Monthly Notices of the Royal       <span>Article history</span><i class=\"icon-general-arrow-filled-down arrow-icon\"></i>\r\n                </a>\r\n        </div>\r\n            <div class=\"history-entries-wrap class=\"center-inner-row\">\r\n        <nav class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"navbar-search-close js_close-navsearch\">Close</a>\r\n                    <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                        <div id=\"MicrositeSearch\" class=\"microsite-search\">\r\n                            <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter\" id=\"navbar-search-filter\">\r\n                                                                    <optgroup label=\"Search within this journal\">\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Issue\" >This issue</option>\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"\" selected=&quot;selected&quot;>All  Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society</option>\r\n\r\n                                    </optgroup>\r\n                                    <optgroup label=\"Search beyond this journal\">\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Parent\" >All  RAS Journals</option>\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Journals\" >All  Journals</option>\r\n                                    </optgroup>\r\n                            </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input microsite-search-term\" type=\"text\" maxlength=\"255\" id=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" title=\"search input\">\r\n\r\n                            <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MicrositeSearchIcon\" class=\"microsite-search-icon navbar-search-submit icon-menu_search\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search</span></a>\r\n\r\n                        </div>\r\n                    </div>                <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We report on deep near-infrared observations obtained with the Wide Field Camera-3 (WFC3) onboard the <em>Hubble</em><em>Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) of the first five confirmed gravitational lensing events discovered by the <em>Herschel</em> Astrophysical Terahertz Large Area Survey (H-ATLAS). We succeed in disentangling the background galaxy from the lens to gain separate photometry of the two components. The <em>HST</em> data allow us to significantly improve on previous constraints of the mass in stars of the lensed galaxy and to perform accurate lens modelling of these systems, as described in the accompanying paper by Dye et\u00a0al. We fit the spectral energy distributions of the background sources from near-IR to millimetre wavelengths and use the magnification factors estimated by Dye et\u00a0al. to derive the <em>intrinsic</em> properties of the lensed galaxies. We find these galaxies to have star-formations rates (SFR)\u00a0\u223c\u00a0400\u20132000\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u00a0yr<sup>\u22121</sup>, with \u223c(6\u201325)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>10</sup>\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub> of their baryonic mass already turned into stars. At these rates of star formation, all remaining molecular gas will be exhausted in less than \u223c100\u00a0Myr, reaching a final mass in stars of a few 10<sup>11</sup>\u8201M<sub>\u2299</sub>. These galaxies are thus proto-ellipticals caught during their major episode of star formation, and observed at the peak epoch (<em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a01.5\u20133) of the cosmic star formation history of the Universe.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: elliptical and lenticular, cD&quot;\">galaxies: elliptical and lenticular, cD</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: evolution&quot;\">galaxies: evolution</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: formation&quot;\">galaxies: formation</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;infrared: galaxies&quot;\">infrared: galaxies</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;submillimetre: galaxies&quot;\">submillimetre: galaxies</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=111794073 id=\"111794073\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Recent evidence indicate that almost all of high-redshift (| $z$ |\u00a0\u2273 1) dust-obscured star-forming galaxies selected in the sub-millimetre (hereafter sub-mm galaxies, or SMGs) with flux density above \u223c100\u8201mJy at 500| $\\,\\mu$ |m are gravitationally lensed by a foreground galaxy or a group/cluster of galaxies (Negrello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>, hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">N10</a>; Conley et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Cox et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Bussmann et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Fu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Wardlow et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). These sub-mm bright sources are rare, their surface density being \u22720.3\u8201deg<sup>\u22122</sup> at <em>F</em><sub>500</sub>\u00a0\u2273 100\u8201mJy (Negrello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) and therefore only detectable in wide-area sub-mm surveys. In fact, sub-mm surveys before the advent of the <em>Herschel</em> Space Observatory (Pilbratt et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) were either limited to small areas of the sky (i.e. &lt;1\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup>) or severely affected by source confusion due to poor spatial resolution (e.g. Coppin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Devlin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Weiss et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The <em>Herschel</em> Astrophysical Terahertz Large Area Survey<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>1</sup></a> (H-ATLAS) (Eales et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>) is the widest area extragalactic survey undertaken with <em>Herschel</em>. It has mapped \u223c570\u8201deg<sup>2</sup> in five bands from 100 to | $500\\,\\mu$ |m, down to around the 250\u2013500\u00a0| $\\mu$ |m confusion limit. The first 16\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> were observed during the Science Demonstration Phase (SDP) and detected 10 extragalactic sources with <em>F</em><sub>500</sub> \u2265 100\u8201mJy. Existing shallow optical and radio data clearly identify four of these as low redshift (i.e. | $z$ |\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.1) spiral galaxies (Baes et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) and one as a radio bright (<em>F</em><sub>1.4\u8201GHz</sub>\u00a0&gt;\u00a0100\u8201mJy) blazar at | $z$ |\u00a0=\u00a01 (Gonzalez-Nuevo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), while the remaining five have sub-mm colours (i.e. 250\u00a0| $\\mu$ |m/350\u00a0| $\\mu$ |m versus 350\u00a0| $\\mu$ |m/500\u00a0| $\\mu$ |m flux ratios) indicative of dusty star-forming galaxies at | $z$ |\u00a0&gt;\u00a01. If SMGs have a steep luminosity function, as several models suggest (Granato et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Lapi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) and recent results support (Eales et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010b</a>; Lapi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Gruppioni et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), their number counts are expected to exhibit a sharp cut-off at bright fluxes (\u224380\u2013100\u00a0mJy at | $500\\,\\mu$ |m). This cut-off implies that only SMGs that have had their flux boosted by an event of gravitational lensing can be detected above this brightness threshold (Negrello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>, see also fig.\u00a01 of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">N10</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To test this prediction, the five sources with <em>F</em><sub>500</sub>\u00a0&gt;\u00a0100\u8201mJy and with high-| $z$ | colours identified in the H-ATLAS/SDP field have been the subject of intensive multiwavelength follow-up observations. The follow-up campaign includes observations from the ground with the Keck telescopes (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">N10</a>), the Submillimetre Array (SMA) (Bussmann et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">N10</a>), the Zpectrometer instrument on the NRAO Robert C. Byrd Green Bank Telescope (GBT) (Frayer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Harris et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), the Z-Spec spectrometer (Lupu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), the IRAM Plateau de Bure Interferometer (PdBI) (Omont et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; George et\u00a0al., in preparation), the Max-Planck Millimeter Bolometer (MAMBO) at the IRAM 30\u00a0m telescope on Pico Veleta (Dannerbauer et\u00a0al., in preparation), the Combined Array for Research in Millimeter-wave Astronomy (CARMA) (Leew et\u00a0al., in preparation), the Jansky Very Large Array (JVLA; Ivison et\u00a0al., in preparation) and also from space with the <em>Spitzer</em> Space Telescope (Hopwood et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and the <em>Herschel</em>/SPIRE Fourier Transform Spectrometer (Valtchanov et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). The detection, in these objects, of carbon monoxide (CO) rotational line emission, which is a tracer of molecular gas associated with star-forming environments, has provided redshifts in the range | $z$ |\u00a0\u223c\u00a01.5\u20133, consistent with what can be inferred from their sub-mm colours (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">N10</a>). In contrast, the same sources are closely aligned with lower redshift (| $z$ |\u00a0&lt;\u00a01) galaxies detected in the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) (Smith et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and in the VISTA Kilo-degree INfrared Galaxy (VIKING) Survey (Fleuren et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), thus confirming the presence of a foreground galaxy acting as a lens. In four of these systems the background galaxy has been clearly resolved into multiple images at 880\u00a0| $\\mu$ |m with the SMA (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">N10</a>; Bussmann et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) thus providing the definitive confirmation of the lensing hypothesis. As part of this extensive follow-up campaign we obtained observations in the near-IR with the Wide Field Camera-3 (WFC3) onboard the <em>Hubble</em><em>Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) during cycle-18, using the wide-J filter F110W and the wide-H filter F160W.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, we report on the results of these observations. We exploit the sub-arcsecond spatial resolution and sensitivity of the <em>HST</em> observations to disentangle the background source from the foreground galaxy to constrain the near-IR emission of the two components separately. A detailed lens modelling of these systems using a \u2018semilinear inversion approach\u2019 is presented in an accompanying paper (Dye et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>, hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D14</a>). The work is organized as follows. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a> we present the <em>HST</em> data. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a> we discuss other ancillary data used to build the panchromatic spectral energy distribution (SED) of the sources. The subtraction of the foreground lens and the measurement of the photometry of the lens and the background galaxy are discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>. A fit to the SED of the lensed galaxy, from optical to millimetre wavelength, with the addition of the near-IR <em>HST</em> points, is performed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>. The results are discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6</a> while Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec7\"></span><a href=\"#sec7\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">7</a> summarizes the main conclusions.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=111794078 id=\"111794078\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 <em>HST</em> DATA</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>HST</em> observations of the five lens candidates presented in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">N10</a> were taken in 2011 April as part of the cycle-18 proposal 12194 (PI: Negrello) using 10 orbits in total, two for each target. Observations were made with the WFC3 using the wide-J filter F110W (peak wavelength 1.15\u00a0| $\\mu$ |m) and the wide-H filter F160W (peak wavelength | $1.545\\,\\mu$ |m), in order to maximize the chance of detection of the background galaxy, whose emission at shorter wavelengths is expected to be dominated by the foreground galaxy. About one and a half orbits were dedicated to observations in the <em>H</em> band with only half an orbit (or less) spent for observations with the F110W filter. This relatively short exposure was aimed at revealing the morphology of the lens, with minimal contamination from the background source. The total exposure times are reported in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. Data were reduced using the <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> MultiDrizzle package. The pixel scale of the Infrared-Camera is 0.128 arcsec but we resampled the images to a finer pixel scale of 0.064 arcsec by exploiting the adopted dither strategy (a sub-pixel dither patter). This provides us with a better sampling of the point spread function (PSF) whose full width at half-maximum (FWHM) is \u223c0.13\u20130.16 arcsec at wavelengths | $\\lambda =1.1\\hbox{--}1.6\\,\\mu$ |m. Cosmic ray rejections and alignments of the individual frames were also addressed before combining and rebinning the images. Multidrizzle parameters were optimized to the final image quality. <em>HST</em> cut-outs around the five targets are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and in the left panels of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. Due to the relatively longer integration times, the combined F160W images exhibit higher signal-to-noise ratio than those obtained with the F110W filter; however the main features revealed in the <em>H</em> band are also captured with the shorter exposures in the <em>J</em> band.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>2</sup></a></p>                        <a id=\"111794080\" scrollto-destination=\"111794080\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/440/3/10.1093_mnras_stu413/3/m_stu413fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611467611&amp;Signature=1q6-0t4hvjMPHKTp6UhQQ5amwtt230q3U8owHNpwpW2bOnUJ2QNDgbR2wvrnu7YN7IegoFmNaql1zZTtO3SBNq5VEaIk2zhdt1KHKo2a2mMA1IvSdPFkcuRPL4DLNmGKx-la~NHYIMnX6DZNZcntprJr9z9OWxMZo7FAxMfM~hVnZhMJnWd2o2nCAZWrsiqzcef5Z8c4tfLoKhVl3RSYZ27~hyRQ0m8VzSdsxwCV4NIPzRmLA1Zy-snMsSG1k2fY8o8KzalW2VpafkkrNN10R82mANieVGe5D5Ct8~MxrmStj1C-VkYA6D-L2u0S21arxJg8xKce5bl38rhU6Bb0Vw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Two-colour postage stamp HST/WFC3 images of the first five confirmed gravitational lensing systems discovered by H-ATLAS (blue for F110W and red for F160W). The position of the five sources in the Herschel/SPIRE map of the H-ATLAS SDP field is indicated by the yellow circles. The scale of the postage stamps is given in arcseconds.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig1.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/111794080/stu413fig1.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig1.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"111794080\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/440/3/10.1093_mnras_stu413/3/stu413fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611467611&Signature=aEEXkS1Wfjn94iTeqhSSdinko679Zc-9fYuxdqwjChadIzYz96xbGYcn-9GAEqey-L-Xrm~0jHGp5N~f3wOnTjbUGQryqb4g2jEYPbrcK8cdLDmxhilUrbVSblphwfuw071fsEjSZlqEhJEJGqyUPLPKkFx2P3lJ7~YOylh3jqyBrykhjVdoQSFjuUnb4rJKBeChuMgBkjxETxkgp2K7aPSVHQwdmRlOVn87dnXhYjkX-SQOZy5TJnC8FiTafV5rqpGjYs6w1aj679v3-3y~0sKJ1UI8KXeSHBqlnb3rpN3usTFuClzLw-6LyAfI942FlSyQ8ziKw8Wa2vzaiihI7g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=111794080&ar=1747562&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig1.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Two-colour postage stamp <em>HST</em>/WFC3 images of the first five confirmed gravitational lensing systems discovered by H-ATLAS (blue for F110W and red for F160W). The position of the five sources in the <em>Herschel</em>/SPIRE map of the H-ATLAS SDP field is indicated by the yellow circles. The scale of the postage stamps is given in arcseconds.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/440/3/10.1093_mnras_stu413/3/m_stu413fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611467611&amp;Signature=1q6-0t4hvjMPHKTp6UhQQ5amwtt230q3U8owHNpwpW2bOnUJ2QNDgbR2wvrnu7YN7IegoFmNaql1zZTtO3SBNq5VEaIk2zhdt1KHKo2a2mMA1IvSdPFkcuRPL4DLNmGKx-la~NHYIMnX6DZNZcntprJr9z9OWxMZo7FAxMfM~hVnZhMJnWd2o2nCAZWrsiqzcef5Z8c4tfLoKhVl3RSYZ27~hyRQ0m8VzSdsxwCV4NIPzRmLA1Zy-snMsSG1k2fY8o8KzalW2VpafkkrNN10R82mANieVGe5D5Ct8~MxrmStj1C-VkYA6D-L2u0S21arxJg8xKce5bl38rhU6Bb0Vw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Two-colour postage stamp HST/WFC3 images of the first five confirmed gravitational lensing systems discovered by H-ATLAS (blue for F110W and red for F160W). The position of the five sources in the Herschel/SPIRE map of the H-ATLAS SDP field is indicated by the yellow circles.        </a></div></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=111794083 id=\"111794083\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 ANCILLARY DATA</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">These <em>HST</em> images represent the latest addition to the already substantial set of photometric and spectroscopic data for these sources that are reported in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, and briefly summarized below.</p>                        <a id=\"111794085\" scrollto-destination=\"111794085\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Photometric data, spectroscopic redshifts and best-fitting SED parameters for the lens and for the background source. At those wavelengths where the separation between the foreground galaxy and the background source was not possible, the total (lens+source) photometry is provided. All the errors correspond to the 68\u00a0per cent confidence interval. Unless otherwise indicated, the data come from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">N10</a>.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>SDP.9<span |\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>| $\\xi _{\\rm dust}^{\\rm (warm)}$ |\u00a0</td><td>0.80| $_{-0.10}^{+0.10}$ |\u00a0</td><td>0.84| $_{-0.08}^{+0.07}$ |\u00a0</td><td>0.72| $_{-0.07}^{+0.06}$ |\u00a0</td><td>0.74| $_{-0.10}^{+0.10}$ |\u00a0</td><td>0.73| $_{-0.11}^{+0.11}$ |\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>M</em><sub>dust</sub>/\u03bc (10<sup>8</sup>\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>)\u00a0</td><td>6.7| $_{-1.0}^{+1.2}$ |\u00a0</td><td>6.6| $_{-0.9}^{+1.1}$ |\u00a0</td><td>28.8| $_{-4.9}^{+7.0}$ |\u00a0</td><td>10.6| $_{-1.9}^{+2.9}$ |\u00a0</td><td>22.7| $_{-4.1}^{+5.8}$ |\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>M</em><sub>*</sub>/\u03bc (10<sup>10</sup>\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>)\u00a0</td><td>7.1| $_{-2.3}^{+4.2}$ |\u00a0</td><td>18.7| $_{-4.5}^{+5.8}$ |\u00a0</td><td>24.2| $_{-4.0}^{+8.6}$ |\u00a0</td><td>6.6| $_{-1.9}^{+2.6}$ |\u00a0</td><td>13.7| $_{-2.5}^{+3.8}$ |\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>M</em><sub>gas</sub>/\u03bc (10<sup>10</sup>\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>)<sup>(<em>e</em>)</sup>\u00a0</td><td>3.4| $_{-0.9}^{+1.2}$ |\u00a0</td><td>3.0| $_{-0.8}^{+1.1}$ |\u00a0</td><td>5.9| $_{-1.6}^{+2.2}$ |\u00a0</td><td>3.3| $_{-0.9}^{+1.2}$ |\u00a0</td><td>5.3| $_{-1.4}^{+2.0}$ |\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>f</em><sub>gas</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0<em>M</em><sub>gas</sub>/(<em>M</em><sub>gas</sub> + <em>M</em><sub>*</sub>)\u00a0</td><td>0.32| $_{-0.10}^{+0.13}$ |\u00a0</td><td>0.14| $_{-0.04}^{+0.06}$ |\u00a0</td><td>0.19| $_{-0.05}^{+0.06}$ |\u00a0</td><td>0.33| $_{-0.09}^{+0.09}$ |\u00a0</td><td>0.28| $_{-0.07}^{+0.08}$ |\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u03c4<sub>gas</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0<em>M</em><sub>gas</sub>/SFR (Myr)\u00a0</td><td>103| $_{-64}^{+236}$ |\u00a0</td><td>57| $_{-23}^{+99}$ |\u00a0</td><td>26| $_{-8}^{+11}$ |\u00a0</td><td>63| $_{-19}^{+27}$ |\u00a0</td><td>50| $_{-18}^{+23}$ |\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>Lens + background
