0.5\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>VIKING\u00a0<em>Y</em> (| $\\mu$ |Jy)\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td><td>53.5 \u00b1 1.1\u00a0</td><td>17.1 \u00b1 1.1\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>VIKING\u00a0<em>J</em> (| $\\mu$ |Jy)\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td><td>78.4 \u00b1 1.1\u00a0</td><td>25.0 \u00b1 3.7\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>VIKING\u00a0<em>H</em> (| $\\mu$ |Jy)\u00a0</td><td>92.4 \u00b1 5.2\u00a0</td><td>120.0 \u00b1 2.8\u00a0</td><td>34.9 \u00b1 3.9\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>VIKING\u00a0<em>Ks</em> (| $\\mu$ |Jy)\u00a0</td><td>123.2 \u00b1 5.4\u00a0</td><td>199.7 \u00b1 2.4\u00a0</td><td>74.5 \u00b1 4.8\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>WISE</em> 3.4\u00a0| $\\mu$ |m (| $\\mu$ |Jy)\u00a0</td><td>218.2 \u00b1 3.9\u00a0</td><td>519 \u00b1 6.9\u00a0</td><td>132.3 \u00b1 3.9\u00a0</td><td>343.2 \u00b1 5.1\u00a0</td><td>208.0 \u00b1 4.3\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WISE 4.6\u00a0| $\\mu$ |m (| $\\mu$ |Jy)\u00a0</td><td>300.6 \u00b1 6.6\u00a0</td><td>632 \u00b1 10\u00a0</td><td>209.1 \u00b1 6.8\u00a0</td><td>303.9 \u00b1 6.9\u00a0</td><td>233.8 \u00b1 7.7\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup>(<em>a</em>)</sup> From Bussmann et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>); <sup>(<em>b</em>)</sup> from Hopwood et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>); <sup>(<em>c</em>)</sup> from Omont et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>); <sup>(<em>d</em>)</sup> from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D14</a>; <sup>(<em>e</em>)</sup> from Frayer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>, table\u00a01, assuming a 30 per cent error) and Lupu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>, table\u00a04, assuming a 30 per cent error); \u2020 \u2018tentative\u2019.</p></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/111794085\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=111794086 id=\"111794086\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 Far-infrared and sub-mm/mm</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Flux density estimates at 100 to 500| $\\,\\mu$ |m are provided by <em>Herschel</em>/PACS (Poglitsch et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) and <em>Herschel</em>/SPIRE (Griffin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), which are used in parallel mode for <em>H</em>-ATLAS. A description of the map-making for the PACS and SPIRE data of the <em>H</em>-ATLAS/SDP field can be found in Ibar et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) and Pascale et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), respectively, while details of the source extraction and flux measurements are given in Rigby et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). The achieved 5\u8201\u03c3 detection limits (including source confusion) are 33.5 to 44.0 mJy/beam from 250 to 500\u00a0| $\\mu$ |m, 132\u00a0mJy/beam at 100\u00a0| $\\mu$ |m and 121\u8201mJy/beam at 160| $\\,\\mu$ |m. The five sources discussed here have, by selection, a flux density above 100\u00a0mJy at 500\u00a0| $\\mu$ |m (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>) and are therefore robustly detected at the SPIRE wavebands. However only three of them are detected in PACS at more than 3\u03c3, namely SDP.9, SDP.11 and SDP.17. One source, SDP.81, was undetected while the other, SDP.130, falls outside the region covered by PACS in parallel mode. Deeper PACS minimaps of these two objects at 70\u00a0| $\\mu$ |m and 160\u00a0| $\\mu$ |m were obtained by Valtchanov et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). Both sources were detected at 160\u00a0| $\\mu$ |m while upper limits on their flux density were obtained at 70\u00a0| $\\mu$ |m.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Follow-up observations with the SMA (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">N10</a>; Bussmann et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) and IRAM/MAMBO (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">N10</a>; Dunnerbauer et\u00a0al., in preparation) provide flux estimates for all five targets at 880\u00a0| $\\mu$ |m and at 1200\u00a0| $\\mu$ |m, respectively.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=111794089 id=\"111794089\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 Optical</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The <em>H</em>-ATLAS/SDP field is covered by the SDSS. Four of the H-ATLAS/SDP lenses have a reliable association in SDSS with <em>r</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a022.40 (Smith et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), the exception being SDP.11, whose optical counterpart has <em>r</em>\u00a0=\u00a022.41. The SDSS flux densities used for the SED fitting in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a> are those derived from the Data Release 7 model magnitudes (see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">N10</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Dedicated follow-up observations with the Keck telescope provided supplementary optical imaging in the <em>g</em> and <em>i</em> bands. As discussed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">N10</a>, the lensed sources are undetected in the optical. The optical flux densities reported in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, derived from the light-profile modelling as described in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">N10</a>, refer to either the whole system (lens+source) or the lens alone when the latter is completely dominating over the background galaxy as suggested by the <em>HST</em> imaging data. Upper limits on the optical emission from the background source are also shown in the table. These limits were derived after subtracting the best-fitting model for the light profile. The local standard deviation was scaled to the area of a ring of radius 1.5 arcsec (inner radius of 1 arcsec and outer radius of 2 arcsec). The limits are not reported for SDP.17; in fact, in this case the <em>HST</em> data suggest (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>) that at optical wavelengths the emission of the source might not be negligible, implying that the <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> model derived from the Keck image carries contributions from both the lens and the background galaxy.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=111794092 id=\"111794092\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3>3.3 Near- and mid-infrared</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Near-IR imaging data are available through the UKIRT Infrared Deep Sky Survey (UKIDSS), Large Area Survey (LAS) and the VIKING (Sutherland et\u00a0al., in preparation) survey (see also Fleuren et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). The VIKING survey is 1.4 mag deeper than UKIDSS/LAS, so we use VIKING data only in the present work. The VIKING survey provides photometric measurements in five broad-band filters: <em>Z</em>, <em>Y</em>, <em>J</em>, <em>H</em>, and <em>Ks</em>, down to a typical 5\u03c3 magnitude limit of 21.0 in <em>J</em> band and 19.2 in <em>Ks</em> band (in the Vega system). The median image quality is \u223c0.9 arcsec. All our targets are found to have a reliable association in the VIKING survey (Fleuren et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). For SED fitting analysis we use VIKING flux densities estimated from aperture photometry with an aperture radius of 2 arcsec for SDP.9 and SDP.11, 1 arcsec for SDP.17, and 4 arcsec for SDP.81 and SDP.130. Associated errors are derived from the distribution of the flux densities values that were obtained by taking aperture photometry at random positions in the field (avoiding the region around detected sources).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For SDP.81 and SDP.130, near-IR imaging data at 3.6 and 4.5| $\\,\\mu$ |m are also available from <em>Spitzer</em> (Hopwood et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). At those wavelengths the emission from the lens and the background galaxy are comparable (i.e. source to lens flux density ratio \u22730.2) and the separation of the two contributions was performed by using the information from the SMA and the Keck data as a prior (see Hopwood et\u00a0al. for details).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Imaging data at 3.4, 4.6, 12 and 22\u00a0| $\\mu$ |m, with an angular resolution of 6.1 arcsec, 6.4 arcsec, 6.5 arcsec and 12.0 arcsec, respectively, are provided by the <em>Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer</em> (<em>WISE</em>) (Wright et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) all sky survey. The <em>WISE</em> images have a 5\u8201\u03c3 photometric sensitivity of 0.068, 0.098, 0.86 and 5.4\u00a0mJy, respectively, in un-confused regions. Postage stamp images centred at the position of the five H-ATLAS/SDP lenses are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. All our targets are detected by the <em>WISE</em> at 3.4\u00a0| $\\mu$ |m (W1) and 4.6\u00a0| $\\mu$ |m (W2) while at 12\u00a0| $\\mu$ |m (W3) and 22\u00a0| $\\mu$ |m (W4) only SDP.9, SDP.17 and SDP.17 have a counterpart in the <em>WISE</em> catalogue. In the following we adopt the <em>WISE</em> flux densities determined by standard profile fitting<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>3</sup></a> as all our targets have extended source flag <em>text| $\\underline{ }$ |flg</em>\u00a0=\u00a00. For SDP.81 and SDP.130 we use the available 95 per cent upper limit at 12 and 22\u00a0| $\\mu$ |m.</p>                        <a id=\"111794096\" scrollto-destination=\"111794096\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/440/3/10.1093_mnras_stu413/3/m_stu413fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611467611&amp;Signature=BuABX1Eo9rWh618q5joPCUwdTTu1jJoKqia5TWjnUMm~D3ZuD5wCZfhp5XX6JQDMJ2wXvIIdEmcxrgP0M-EoRn9Fq6OyGgcIHmZoOtjxqUi4Zb4c0uDgzG1JbJslWHhc5ZZ3Kpz8h1HtnZta4xtAiuoUzAi62E-qt8nb-zq2C0ZkPjKkjEX96MX0XQA0P6C7AVGYObB0qpLh6J4NMxuKNJwdbioS0EZp~1gSZMO0p-0nz22bwabyhvRGrL3N~dQv0OqHsTmKYGedYbfZi7hGK40IA7UIR1qpkh56WSvoadeN9U2ERnZfLgI9NyHtl87OWj4Sv~li2BATbCkhLqutwA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"40\u00a0\u00d7\u00a040 arcsec2 postage stamp images of the five H-ATLAS/SDP lensing systems at near- to mid-infrared wavelengths obtained from the VIKING and WISE surveys. The stamps are centred at the position of the lensed galaxy.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig3.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/111794096/stu413fig3.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig3.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"111794096\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/440/3/10.1093_mnras_stu413/3/stu413fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611467611&Signature=m4-0wK8TjVyWcRVrSxlNd0O85GMPnk1YsKvEVmfQxx~j4V3PP8e531BiozoDDfaCGfeO0jZXuU1CqCV~1sGaqgHSQWMhqHmSivEXr-KpcoCg2HjOFVDYz32Lj2xDNnZ3B9Qr6qPcJVhbn1LIQPFrU7hQ0i7XnSUA5Wc3duBoJJij2UtXsUDJZ9KBfUBVABjw998Vy7bsdvbCPPg~eAuIi1vKEPINfyrokEfX7zAb8DIe6hjV1Jjy9SBESZYibHJLUiW6XL9cnAlRHLRn4FcFZFhzo5TlbeOOKV5fujO7Op-2U422CvgmVF5w9tWvkClF5kPIc8mi6zFStY8grRonJQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=111794096&ar=1747562&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig3.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">40\u00a0\u00d7\u00a040 arcsec<sup>2</sup> postage stamp images of the five H-ATLAS/SDP lensing systems at near- to mid-infrared wavelengths obtained from the VIKING and <em>WISE</em> surveys. The stamps are centred at the position of the lensed galaxy.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/440/3/10.1093_mnras_stu413/3/m_stu413fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611467611&amp;Signature=BuABX1Eo9rWh618q5joPCUwdTTu1jJoKqia5TWjnUMm~D3ZuD5wCZfhp5XX6JQDMJ2wXvIIdEmcxrgP0M-EoRn9Fq6OyGgcIHmZoOtjxqUi4Zb4c0uDgzG1JbJslWHhc5ZZ3Kpz8h1HtnZta4xtAiuoUzAi62E-qt8nb-zq2C0ZkPjKkjEX96MX0XQA0P6C7AVGYObB0qpLh6J4NMxuKNJwdbioS0EZp~1gSZMO0p-0nz22bwabyhvRGrL3N~dQv0OqHsTmKYGedYbfZi7hGK40IA7UIR1qpkh56WSvoadeN9U2ERnZfLgI9NyHtl87OWj4Sv~li2BATbCkhLqutwA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"40\u00a0\u00d7\u00a040 arcsec2 postage stamp images of the five H-ATLAS/SDP lensing systems at near- to mid-infrared wavelengths obtained from the VIKING and WISE surveys. The stamps are centred at the position of the lensed galaxy.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig3.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/111794096/stu413fig3.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig3.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"111794096\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/440/3/10.1093_mnras_stu413/3/stu413fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611467611&Signature=m4-0wK8TjVyWcRVrSxlNd0O85GMPnk1YsKvEVmfQxx~j4V3PP8e531BiozoDDfaCGfeO0jZXuU1CqCV~1sGaqgHSQWMhqHmSivEXr-KpcoCg2HjOFVDYz32Lj2xDNnZ3B9Qr6qPcJVhbn1LIQPFrU7hQ0i7XnSUA5Wc3duBoJJij2UtXsUDJZ9KBfUBVABjw998Vy7bsdvbCPPg~eAuIi1vKEPINfyrokEfX7zAb8DIe6hjV1Jjy9SBESZYibHJLUiW6XL9cnAlRHLRn4FcFZFhzo5TlbeOOKV5fujO7Op-2U422CvgmVF5w9tWvkClF5kPIc8mi6zFStY8grRonJQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=111794096&ar=1747562&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig3.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">40\u00a0\u00d7\u00a040 arcsec<sup>2</sup> postage stamp images of the five H-ATLAS/SDP lensing systems at near- to mid-infrared wavelengths obtained from the VIKING and <em>WISE</em> surveys. The stamps are centred at the position of the lensed galaxy.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=111794097 id=\"111794097\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-4>3.4 Spectroscopic redshifts</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">For all our targets the redshift of the background galaxy has been constrained through the detection of CO emission lines by Z-spec (Lupu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), GBT/Zpec (Frayer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Harris et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), PdBI (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">N10</a>; George et\u00a0al., in preparation; Omont et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) and CARMA (Leew et\u00a0al., in preparation). H<sub>2</sub>O was detected in SDP.17 (Omont et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), SDP.9 and SDP.81 (Omont et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) with PdBI, while emission from [C\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] and [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] has been measured in SDP.81 (Valtchanov et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). Optical spectra of the foreground galaxy were taken with the William Herschel Telescope (WHT) for SDP.11 and SDP.17 and with the Apache Point Observatory 3.5-m telescope for SDP.130 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">N10</a>), giving spectroscopic redshifts in the range | $z$ |<sub>spec</sub>\u00a0= 0.22\u20130.94. For SDP.81 an optical spectrum was already available via SDSS, which gives | $z$ |<sub>spec</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.299. SDP.9 has an optical spectroscopic redshift | $z$ |<sub>spec</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.613 recently obtained with the Gemini-South telescope (Bussmann et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). A summary of available photometric and spectroscopic information is given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=111794099 id=\"111794099\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 LENS SUBTRACTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">According to Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> (left panels), the <em>HST</em> data alone strongly support the idea of a gravitational lensing event in three of the five targets, namely SDP.9, SDP.11 and SDP.17, through the detection of a diffuse ring-like structure around a central elliptical galaxy. Hints of lensing are also found in the WFC3 images of SDP.81, where a faint arclet is visible \u223c1.5 arcsec away from the central elliptical galaxy in the west direction. For SDP.130 no clear evidence of gravitational lensing can be claimed from the <em>HST</em> images alone, where the system resembles a lenticular galaxy.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to unveil the full morphology of the lensed source, the light profile of the foreground galaxy needs to be fitted and subtracted. We use the <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> software (Peng et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>) to construct models of the light profiles for each lensing system. <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> performs a non-linear 2D minimization and allows multiple profiles to be simultaneously fitted. As these lensing systems are photometrically blended in the <em>HST</em> data, in order to achieve a good fit to the lens galaxy it is necessary to fit profiles to both the lens and source components in the same model. Once a satisfactory model is achieved for the whole system, only the best-fitting lens profile is then subtracted. If there are other sources within the fitting region they are either masked or, if close enough to the main source to cause significant photometric blending, are included in the fit (e.g. the edge-on galaxy at the north-west side of SDP.11; Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). Where available, sub-arcsecond resolution ancillary data (e.g. from the SMA) are used to guide the fitting process. For each image, nearby stars were combined to give an empirical PSF. All star candidates were checked for saturation, normalized and re-centred before being median combined. For SDP.11 only one suitable star is available.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For each image initially one S\u00e9rsic profile was fitted to the foreground lens in order to gauge the level of lensed structure above the detection limit. Then each <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> model is built up by adding extra profiles until both the lens and source galaxy components are well represented. The process is iterative and follows the basic loop of applying <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span>, inspecting the results, adjusting the parameters and possibly adding more complexity where necessary before re-applying <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span>. This is a process that relies on thorougher visual inspection at each stage, with comparison to other available data, such as the SMA data to check the profiles/model associated with the lensed structure. The fitting process generally started with the higher signal-to-noise ratio F160W image, and then these results used as a prior for the initial guess for F110W. A close eye was kept to try and maintain a reasonable similarity in the profile orientation and ellipticity for both bands, where that was possible. The resulting lens-subtracted images are shown in the right panels of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> and compared with the signal-to-noise ratio contours at 880| $\\,\\mu$ |m from the SMA (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">N10</a>; Bussmann et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Below we discuss the <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> results for the five sources individually.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>SDP.9</strong>. The foreground galaxy is fitted with a single S\u00e9rsic profile of index <em>n</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0= 5.1 in F110W and <em>n</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0= 5.8 in F160W. The light profile is therefore consistent with that of an elliptical galaxy. After the subtraction of the lens, a diffuse ring-like structure is clearly revealed, particularly at 1.6| $\\,\\mu$ |m. The ring contains two main knots of near-IR emission to the north and south of the lens position and two fainter ones to the east and west.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>SDP.11</strong>. This is the 500| $\\,\\mu$ |m brightest lens candidate selected in the H-ATLAS/SDP field (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>) and even without the subtraction of the foreground galaxy it is clear that the background source is lensed into an Einstein ring. The ring is particularly elongated with a significant amount of substructure, which suggests the presence of several clumps of rest-frame UV/optical emission in the source plane (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D14</a>), consistent with what was found for the H-ATLAS lensed galaxy presented in Fu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). The foreground galaxy required two S\u00e9rsic profiles in each of the bands, where one profile is approximately an exponential disc (<em>n</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a01) and the other profile has index <em>n</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0= 2.8 at 1.1| $\\,\\mu$ |m and <em>n</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0= 4.5 and 1.6| $\\,\\mu$ |m. Also in this case the light profile is indicative of an elliptical/lenticular galaxy.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>SDP.17</strong>. At first glance, this system resembles a face-on spiral galaxy with two prominent spiral arms. However we know from spectroscopic follow-up observations that this system has an optical redshift of 0.9435 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">N10</a>) and a redshift of 2.305 from the detection of both CO (Lupu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Harris et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) and <em>H</em><sub>2</sub>0 (Omont et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) lines, thus indicating the presence of two objects along the same line of sight. Follow-up observations with the SMA (Bussmann et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) show that the sub-mm/mm emission is relatively compact, concentrated within \u223c0.6 arcsec from the centre of the source, but fails to resolve the individual lensed images.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A satisfactory fit to the observed light distribution of this object requires eight profiles as illustrated in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>: two accounts for the innermost region (i.e. that within \u22720.3\u8201arcsec from the centre), one with S\u00e9rsic index <em>n</em><sub>s, 1</sub>\u00a0\u2273 10 and the another one (less extended) with <em>n</em><sub>s, 2</sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.6 (at both 1.1 and 1.6\u00a0| $\\mu$ |m). We assume that these two profiles describe the foreground galaxy (or at least most of it), which is acting as a lens. The other six profiles may either be all associated with the lensed source or, at least some of them, may belong to the foreground galaxy. In order to understand the more likely scenario, we have derived the 1.6-| $\\mu$ |m to 1.1-| $\\mu$ |m flux density ratio, <em>F</em><sub>1.6</sub>/<em>F</em><sub>1.1</sub>, for each of the outermost profiles. In fact, if the lens had spiral arms then we would expect the arms to display bluer colours than the bulge and the ratio <em>F</em><sub>1.6</sub>/<em>F</em><sub>1.1</sub> would decrease from the centre towards the outer regions of the galaxy. On the contrary, if the spiral-arms-like structure is part of the lensed source then the same flux density ratio would increase towards the edges of the image, thus reflecting the reddening of the SED of the background galaxy, due to both high redshift and dust extinction (although examples of sub-mm selected galaxies comprising some relatively \u2018blue\u2019 components exist; see e.g. Ivison et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). The measured flux density ratios are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> (right panel). We find that the profile labelled as 8 is significantly bluer than the lens. It might be either another foreground object, not necessarily associated with the lens, or a small star-forming region in the lens itself, which could explain the detection of the lens in CO in the Z-spec spectrum (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">N10</a>). If it was a dust-free region in the source plane its lensed counter-image would have a similar 1.6-| $\\mu$ |m to 1.1-| $\\mu$ |m flux density ratio, but this is not the case. Indeed, all the other outer profiles have either redder colours than the lens (e.g. profile 3 and profile 7) or colours similar to it. Also, if \u2018blob\u2019 8 was at | $z$ |\u00a0=\u00a02.3 then the F110W and F160W filters would sample the opposite sides of the Balmer (3646\u00a0\u00c5) and the 4000\u00a0\u00c5 break. Altogether they would give, generally, <em>F</em><sub>1.6</sub>/<em>F</em><sub>1.1</sub>\u00a0&gt;\u00a01.5 unless the galaxy is very young (i.e. &lt;10<sup>8</sup>\u8201yr) and dust-free. Therefore the profile labelled as 8 is most likely associated with the foreground galaxy while the other profiles 3\u22124\u22125\u22126\u22127 are probably suffering some contamination of their colours by the foreground galaxy. In light of these considerations, in this work and in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D14</a> we assume that the lensed object is made up of profiles 3\u22124\u22125\u22126\u22127.</p>                        <a id=\"111794107\" scrollto-destination=\"111794107\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/440/3/10.1093_mnras_stu413/3/m_stu413fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611467611&amp;Signature=kvfZzA1ngy-Lcczf7mS3l8a3SNT-AMg9wE5xQxfSc2qkRiDnTa4PQKTMXUi2U7wYFDERyho380LDRgNru4ZcIGlXMRQFtIJBVI-IYuIXLMmNP28w42lyVNeEY3HvZqSmkLWGqJD~G9LmvmnDYBZ9igW8tE6foFIO4HJB1keIOq7m00HTU1c813sSRmOWh1Sgv9boDXw~EeFJ0bb9qYnkbHZDj2lT3boUovwts9Y0gF2OJo3Rx4w-9CaJ6RKLF0eA6uWfdEzaYLeaUQFm8axbr-3g1Fv-lgnBqP-AZ2ev-4-SvRjQc~yUAjVkDB4iBPGOFYCJPjzVKBmb-AXOMOg2mQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"galfit results for SDP.17 at 1.1 $\\,\\mu$ m (top panels) and at 1.6 $\\,\\mu$ m (bottom panels). From left to right shown are the input image, the model inner profiles (that we assume describe the lens), the model outer profiles, and the residuals. The 1.6- to 1.1- $\\mu$ m flux density ratios of the outer profiles (marked by numbers in figure) are shown in the right panel and compared with the 1.6- to 1.1- $\\mu$ m flux density ratio of the two inner profiles (yellow shaded region). If the outer profiles are part of the lensed source then their near-IR flux density ratio would increase towards the edges of the image, thus reflecting the reddening of the SED of the background galaxy, due to both high redshift and dust extinction. This is only the case for profile 8. Therefore the background source is assumed to comprise profiles 3\u22124\u22125\u22126\u22127.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig4.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/111794107/stu413fig4.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig4.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"111794107\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/440/3/10.1093_mnras_stu413/3/stu413fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611467611&Signature=Egiimuo2TmOaB7v2Il6-ExKtGo8zoc7rK-QAP8oQVmX-l-wIfvaaTn-I~BpFPg4UQKxLZW3gNV0-QI6n-7G2NnE9CyVmr0QzBBPfcsfdPR5evIsPQjNmoNbOrazmDnugi6e5Cq2DbNMysjx-4qzBVduBQo4DBGOV6AeEF7KictPvsBxSNZFK1uM0Guc8WBWApD08405NGJSu7Dq5gYC5zwECvOS-~e-5eR3XQtK4h0FgRaC4YO9~oHvBHUUcEuMD9rI78yV6umPi6UVY8~iHJOR45~-trutuWsQwTMYV5q5~KdwLLdrYMpFAKYr62F-cGD-yhEq0UUd4Qv22vHdRDw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=111794107&ar=1747562&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig4.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> results for SDP.17 at 1.1| $\\,\\mu$ |m (top panels) and at 1.6| $\\,\\mu$ |m (bottom panels). From left to right shown are the input image, the model inner profiles (that we assume describe the lens), the model outer profiles, and the residuals. The 1.6- to 1.1-| $\\mu$ |m flux density ratios of the outer profiles (marked by numbers in figure) are shown in the right panel and compared with the 1.6- to 1.1-| $\\mu$ |m flux density ratio of the two inner profiles (yellow shaded region). If the outer profiles are part of the lensed source then their near-IR flux density ratio would increase towards the edges of the image, thus reflecting the reddening of the SED of the background galaxy, due to both high redshift and dust extinction. This is only the case for profile 8. Therefore the background source is assumed to comprise profiles 3\u22124\u22125\u22126\u22127.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/440/3/10.1093_mnras_stu413/3/m_stu413fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611467611&amp;Signature=kvfZzA1ngy-Lcczf7mS3l8a3SNT-AMg9wE5xQxfSc2qkRiDnTa4PQKTMXUi2U7wYFDERyho380LDRgNru4ZcIGlXMRQFtIJBVI-IYuIXLMmNP28w42lyVNeEY3HvZqSmkLWGqJD~G9LmvmnDYBZ9igW8tE6foFIO4HJB1keIOq7m00HTU1c813sSRmOWh1Sgv9boDXw~EeFJ0bb9qYnkbHZDj2lT3boUovwts9Y0gF2OJo3Rx4w-9CaJ6RKLF0eA6uWfdEzaYLeaUQFm8axbr-3g1Fv-lgnBqP-AZ2ev-4-SvRjQc~yUAjVkDB4iBPGOFYCJPjzVKBmb-AXOMOg2mQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"galfit results for SDP.17 at 1.1 $\\,\\mu$ m (top panels) and at 1.6 $\\,\\mu$ m (bottom panels). From left to right shown are the input image, the model inner profiles (that we assume describe the lens), the model outer profiles, and the residuals. The 1.6- to 1.1- $\\mu$ m flux density ratios of the outer profiles (marked by numbers in figure) are shown in the right panel and compared with the 1.6- to 1.1- $\\mu$ m flux density ratio of the two inner profiles (yellow shaded region). If the outer profiles are part of the lensed source then their near-IR flux density ratio would increase towards the edges of the image, thus reflecting the reddening of the SED of the background galaxy, due to both high redshift and dust extinction. This is only the case for profile 8. Therefore the background source is assumed to comprise profiles 3\u22124\u22125\u22126\u22127.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig4.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/111794107/stu413fig4.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig4.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"111794107\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/440/3/10.1093_mnras_stu413/3/stu413fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611467611&Signature=Egiimuo2TmOaB7v2Il6-ExKtGo8zoc7rK-QAP8oQVmX-l-wIfvaaTn-I~BpFPg4UQKxLZW3gNV0-QI6n-7G2NnE9CyVmr0QzBBPfcsfdPR5evIsPQjNmoNbOrazmDnugi6e5Cq2DbNMysjx-4qzBVduBQo4DBGOV6AeEF7KictPvsBxSNZFK1uM0Guc8WBWApD08405NGJSu7Dq5gYC5zwECvOS-~e-5eR3XQtK4h0FgRaC4YO9~oHvBHUUcEuMD9rI78yV6umPi6UVY8~iHJOR45~-trutuWsQwTMYV5q5~KdwLLdrYMpFAKYr62F-cGD-yhEq0UUd4Qv22vHdRDw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=111794107&ar=1747562&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig4.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> results for SDP.17 at 1.1| $\\,\\mu$ |m (top panels) and at 1.6| $\\,\\mu$ |m (bottom panels). From left to right shown are the input image, the model inner profiles (that we assume describe the lens), the model outer profiles, and the residuals. The 1.6- to 1.1-| $\\mu$ |m flux density ratios of the outer profiles (marked by numbers in figure) are shown in the right panel and compared with the 1.6- to 1.1-| $\\mu$ |m flux density ratio of the two inner profiles (yellow shaded region). If the outer profiles are part of the lensed source then their near-IR flux density ratio would increase towards the edges of the image, thus reflecting the reddening of the SED of the background galaxy, due to both high redshift and dust extinction. This is only the case for profile 8. Therefore the background source is assumed to comprise profiles 3\u22124\u22125\u22126\u22127.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>SDP.81</strong>. The fit to the Keck image performed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">N10</a> required two profiles: a compact elliptical S\u00e9rsic core plus a subdominant exponential disc. Two S\u00e9rsic profiles are required to achieve a good lens subtraction in both <em>HST</em> bands, with indexes <em>n</em><sub>s, 1</sub>\u00a0= 2.3 and <em>n</em><sub>s, 2</sub>\u00a0= 2.0 for F110W, and <em>n</em><sub>s, 1</sub>\u00a0= 2.9 and <em>n</em><sub>s, 2</sub>\u00a0= 0.9 for F160W. Once the lens is subtracted (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>), two arclets, on opposite sides with respect to the centre of the lens, are revealed. The smaller one, on the west, was barely visible before the subtraction of the lens. The remarkable similarity of the residuals to the structure revealed in the sub-mm by the SMA (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>) supports the robustness of the lens fitting procedure.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>SDP.130</strong>. This system was also fitted in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">N10</a> using two profiles: a compact elliptical S\u00e9rsic core plus an exponential disc. In the <em>HST</em> images the exponential disc is now clearly resolved into two diffuse spiral arms. The lens galaxy can thus be classified as an Sa galaxy. The arm extending in the south-east direction reveals a substructure oriented in an almost orthogonal direction to the arm itself. This small structure produces some emission in the sub-mm (detected with the SMA; Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>) and may suggest that an interaction of the arm with another object is on-going and is triggering some star-formation activity. Another structure is visible close to the bulge, in the north-west direction, but is undetected by the SMA. Its nature is unclear. Overall, the morphology of this system in the <em>HST</em> images is not suggestive of a lensing event. This is because, in the near-IR, the lensed object is masked by the prominent bulge of the foreground galaxy. The subtraction of the lens is therefore necessary to reveal the background source.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">SDP.130 presents the greatest challenge of the five lenses in terms of subtracting off the lensing galaxy light profile. With the superior resolution of the <em>HST</em> images it is now clear that spiral arms are present, although possibly these have suffered some disruption via the interaction with a smaller object (the one to the south-east mentioned before) and now form more of an elongated ring. In addition, there may be a bar structure across the bulge. The <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> model of the lens is thus made up of multiple profiles fitted to the bulge, the bar, the spiral arms and the small interacting object. The final model has 16 fitted profiles in all, five associated with the lensing galaxy core, where three profiles represent the bulge and two the bar \u2018ends\u2019. As shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, the two profiles representing the lensed structure correspond well to the two most prominent knots seen in the SMA data. Overall SDP.130 is well subtracted.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=111794111 id=\"111794111\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 SPECTRAL ENERGY DISTRIBUTIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> decomposition allows us to measure the photometry of the lensing galaxy and of the background source separately. We use aperture photometry on the <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> best-fitting model images to derive the flux densities at 1.1 and 1.6| $\\,\\mu$ |m. Photometric errors are obtained by taking aperture photometry of the sky (with the same aperture radius used to measure the flux of the targets) at random positions and estimating the corresponding rms. The results are listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> and shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a> (coloured circles: orange for the background source and cyan for the foreground galaxy) together with other available photometric data.</p>                        <a id=\"111794113\" scrollto-destination=\"111794113\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/440/3/10.1093_mnras_stu413/3/m_stu413fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611467611&amp;Signature=YurkynRXsLWM2I2O7cYJJ08KF0W6gqmmoNx-ldIAERPcY8nYimmSWRH3f8K6RLz60b3djJF9JXtTliX0e4rILfrIneayNrM5PZNfCBxaMEhkXI~I6kI2L25Ntr9ImyafN0GFX~u0n-wxCl1p65pX35cVAbmilszWe6yE7RuuiAqsP--cU4hQCM0jeAjhKdOMzWddRHkOnCjQP65qBMp3mDT4tMGUSwQfOMwmgF5BridfjLTQdQEyjSgd3pmV2mBdtFEF-flIoTkzJygYWQqBmMBI7~yAYpNPCmPTsktrZA3wei7oY~5euyuVFIqdsh8DV59Aj0eHO0wYpw9ZjGTM-g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"SEDs of the lens and of the background source for the five H-ATLAS/SDP gravitational lensing systems. The new photometric data points from HST/WFC3 are indicated by filled circles (cyan for the lens and orange for the background source) while other existing photometric data are represented with either error bars or downward arrows in case of upper limits. The optical data are from SDSS and Keck while measurements at near/mid-IR are from VIKING, WISE, and Spitzer. The sub-mm/millimetre photometry is from PACS/Herschel, SPIRE/Herschel, SMA and MAMBO/IRAM. Upper limits at PACS/Herschel wavelengths are shown at 3\u8201\u03c3. Data points are blue for the lens photometry, red for the background source photometry and black for the lens+source photometry. The best-fitting SED is in cyan for the lens and in orange for the source. The thick grey line is their sum. For SDP.9 and SDP.11 the lighter orange curve shows the best-fitting results for the lensed source when the WISE data points at 12 and 22 $\\,\\mu$ m are included in the fit. For SDP.130, the dashed curve is the best-fitting SED obtained for the lensed source when the Keck upper limits are also taken into account.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig5.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/111794113/stu413fig5.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig5.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"111794113\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/440/3/10.1093_mnras_stu413/3/stu413fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611467611&Signature=5IKsiZo1zHCFhRBxkfD8-WKeNryIrWBZnWrkf3f9AIo27hbzUst64lEY1VIoWVkkVUyb1pWPX5CcPYpbQV6Ay~MjUnDm2OKHb0n50P~AQ-jPnSrQ-lrpIDp9FkCE5ZmuFJlcAmYmole6tE9yAm4UEseC7odzgCtj51keQkCm21ixWEL240qp2HaDQ~oo4xgPFXPe~La~ehEF6iVKHpORIXX-9CCTTNrNJPk9rNS4bOK3byjouclZ7ORKThkcpu5fVmGmuQ8ryYECDGUrpjlJAhfg8pM83yuv7W3t4-dVDEnlPJTUeIDW0UFNc18E8zHMhjhHgjh9huyz1Uy6DewYsA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=111794113&ar=1747562&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig5.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">SEDs of the lens and of the background source for the five H-ATLAS/SDP gravitational lensing systems.
