From left to right shown are the input image, the model inner profiles (that we assume describe the lens), the model outer profiles, and the residuals. The 1.6- to 1.1-| $\\mu$ |m flux density ratios of the outer profiles (marked by numbers in figure) are shown in the right panel and compared with the 1.6- to 1.1-| $\\mu$ |m flux density ratio of the two inner profiles (yellow shaded region). If the outer profiles are part of the lensed source then their near-IR flux density ratio would increase towards the edges of the image, thus reflecting the reddening of the SED of the background galaxy, due to both high redshift and dust extinction. This is only the case for profile 8. Therefore the background source is assumed to comprise profiles 3\u22124\u22125\u22126\u22127.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/440/3/10.1093_mnras_stu413/3/m_stu413fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611467611&amp;Signature=kvfZzA1ngy-Lcczf7mS3l8a3SNT-AMg9wE5xQxfSc2qkRiDnTa4PQKTMXUi2U7wYFDERyho380LDRgNru4ZcIGlXMRQFtIJBVI-IYuIXLMmNP28w42lyVNeEY3HvZqSmkLWGqJD~G9LmvmnDYBZ9igW8tE6foFIO4HJB1keIOq7m00HTU1c813sSRmOWh1Sgv9boDXw~EeFJ0bb9qYnkbHZDj2lT3boUovwts9Y0gF2OJo3Rx4w-9CaJ6RKLF0eA6uWfdEzaYLeaUQFm8axbr-3g1Fv-lgnBqP-AZ2ev-4-SvRjQc~yUAjVkDB4iBPGOFYCJPjzVKBmb-AXOMOg2mQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"galfit results for SDP.17 at 1.1 $\\,\\mu$ m (top panels) and at 1.6 $\\,\\mu$ m (bottom panels). From left to right shown are the input image, the model inner profiles (that we assume describe the lens), the model outer profiles, and the residuals. The 1.6- to 1.1- $\\mu$ m flux density ratios of the outer profiles (marked by numbers in figure) are shown in the right panel and compared with the 1.6- to 1.1- $\\mu$ m flux density ratio of the two inner profiles (yellow shaded region). If the outer profiles are part of the lensed source then their near-IR flux density ratio would increase towards the edges of the image, thus reflecting the reddening of the SED of the background galaxy, due to both high redshift and dust extinction. This is only the case for profile 8. Therefore the background source is assumed to comprise profiles 3\u22124\u22125\u22126\u22127.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig4.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/111794107/stu413fig4.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig4.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"111794107\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/440/3/10.1093_mnras_stu413/3/stu413fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611467611&Signature=Egiimuo2TmOaB7v2Il6-ExKtGo8zoc7rK-QAP8oQVmX-l-wIfvaaTn-I~BpFPg4UQKxLZW3gNV0-QI6n-7G2NnE9CyVmr0QzBBPfcsfdPR5evIsPQjNmoNbOrazmDnugi6e5Cq2DbNMysjx-4qzBVduBQo4DBGOV6AeEF7KictPvsBxSNZFK1uM0Guc8WBWApD08405NGJSu7Dq5gYC5zwECvOS-~e-5eR3XQtK4h0FgRaC4YO9~oHvBHUUcEuMD9rI78yV6umPi6UVY8~iHJOR45~-trutuWsQwTMYV5q5~KdwLLdrYMpFAKYr62F-cGD-yhEq0UUd4Qv22vHdRDw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=111794107&ar=1747562&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig4.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> results for SDP.17 at 1.1| $\\,\\mu$ |m (top panels) and at 1.6| $\\,\\mu$ |m (bottom panels). From left to right shown are the input image, the model inner profiles (that we assume describe the lens), the model outer profiles, and the residuals. The 1.6- to 1.1-| $\\mu$ |m flux density ratios of the outer profiles (marked by numbers in figure) are shown in the right panel and compared with the 1.6- to 1.1-| $\\mu$ |m flux density ratio of the two inner profiles (yellow shaded region). If the outer profiles are part of the lensed source then their near-IR flux density ratio would increase towards the edges of the image, thus reflecting the reddening of the SED of the background galaxy, due to both high redshift and dust extinction. This is only the case for profile 8. Therefore the background source is assumed to comprise profiles 3\u22124\u22125\u22126\u22127.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>SDP.81</strong>. The fit to the Keck image performed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">N10</a> required two profiles: a compact elliptical S\u00e9rsic core plus a subdominant exponential disc. Two S\u00e9rsic profiles are required to achieve a good lens subtraction in both <em>HST</em> bands, with indexes <em>n</em><sub>s, 1</sub>\u00a0= 2.3 and <em>n</em><sub>s, 2</sub>\u00a0= 2.0 for F110W, and <em>n</em><sub>s, 1</sub>\u00a0= 2.9 and <em>n</em><sub>s, 2</sub>\u00a0= 0.9 for F160W. Once the lens is subtracted (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>), two arclets, on opposite sides with respect to the centre of the lens, are revealed. The smaller one, on the west, was barely visible before the subtraction of the lens. The remarkable similarity of the residuals to the structure revealed in the sub-mm by the SMA (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>) supports the robustness of the lens fitting procedure.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>SDP.130</strong>. This system was also fitted in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">N10</a> using two profiles: a compact elliptical S\u00e9rsic core plus an exponential disc. In the <em>HST</em> images the exponential disc is now clearly resolved into two diffuse spiral arms. The lens galaxy can thus be classified as an Sa galaxy. The arm extending in the south-east direction reveals a substructure oriented in an almost orthogonal direction to the arm itself. This small structure produces some emission in the sub-mm (detected with the SMA; Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>) and may suggest that an interaction of the arm with another object is on-going and is triggering some star-formation activity. Another structure is visible close to the bulge, in the north-west direction, but is undetected by the SMA. Its nature is unclear. Overall, the morphology of this system in the <em>HST</em> images is not suggestive of a lensing event. This is because, in the near-IR, the lensed object is masked by the prominent bulge of the foreground galaxy. The subtraction of the lens is therefore necessary to reveal the background source.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">SDP.130 presents the greatest challenge of the five lenses in terms of subtracting off the lensing galaxy light profile. With the superior resolution of the <em>HST</em> images it is now clear that spiral arms are present, although possibly these have suffered some disruption via the interaction with a smaller object (the one to the south-east mentioned before) and now form more of an elongated ring. In addition, there may be a bar structure across the bulge. The <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> model of the lens is thus made up of multiple profiles fitted to the bulge, the bar, the spiral arms and the small interacting object. The final model has 16 fitted profiles in all, five associated with the lensing galaxy core, where three profiles represent the bulge and two the bar \u2018ends\u2019. As shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, the two profiles representing the lensed structure correspond well to the two most prominent knots seen in the SMA data. Overall SDP.130 is well subtracted.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=111794111 id=\"111794111\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 SPECTRAL ENERGY DISTRIBUTIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> decomposition allows us to measure the photometry of the lensing galaxy and of the background source separately. We use aperture photometry on the <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> best-fitting model images to derive the flux densities at 1.1 and 1.6| $\\,\\mu$ |m. Photometric errors are obtained by taking aperture photometry of the sky (with the same aperture radius used to measure the flux of the targets) at random positions and estimating the corresponding rms. The results are listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> and shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a> (coloured circles: orange for the background source and cyan for the foreground galaxy) together with other available photometric data.</p>                        <a id=\"111794113\" scrollto-destination=\"111794113\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/440/3/10.1093_mnras_stu413/3/m_stu413fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611467611&amp;Signature=YurkynRXsLWM2I2O7cYJJ08KF0W6gqmmoNx-ldIAERPcY8nYimmSWRH3f8K6RLz60b3djJF9JXtTliX0e4rILfrIneayNrM5PZNfCBxaMEhkXI~I6kI2L25Ntr9ImyafN0GFX~u0n-wxCl1p65pX35cVAbmilszWe6yE7RuuiAqsP--cU4hQCM0jeAjhKdOMzWddRHkOnCjQP65qBMp3mDT4tMGUSwQfOMwmgF5BridfjLTQdQEyjSgd3pmV2mBdtFEF-flIoTkzJygYWQqBmMBI7~yAYpNPCmPTsktrZA3wei7oY~5euyuVFIqdsh8DV59Aj0eHO0wYpw9ZjGTM-g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"SEDs of the lens and of the background source for the five H-ATLAS/SDP gravitational lensing systems. The new photometric data points from HST/WFC3 are indicated by filled circles (cyan for the lens and orange for the background source) while other existing photometric data are represented with either error bars or downward arrows in case of upper limits. The optical data are from SDSS and Keck while measurements at near/mid-IR are from VIKING, WISE, and Spitzer. The sub-mm/millimetre photometry is from PACS/Herschel, SPIRE/Herschel, SMA and MAMBO/IRAM. Upper limits at PACS/Herschel wavelengths are shown at 3\u8201\u03c3. Data points are blue for the lens photometry, red for the background source photometry and black for the lens+source photometry. The best-fitting SED is in cyan for the lens and in orange for the source. The thick grey line is their sum. For SDP.9 and SDP.11 the lighter orange curve shows the best-fitting results for the lensed source when the WISE data points at 12 and 22 $\\,\\mu$ m are included in the fit. For SDP.130, the dashed curve is the best-fitting SED obtained for the lensed source when the Keck upper limits are also taken into account.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig5.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/111794113/stu413fig5.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig5.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"111794113\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/440/3/10.1093_mnras_stu413/3/stu413fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611467611&Signature=5IKsiZo1zHCFhRBxkfD8-WKeNryIrWBZnWrkf3f9AIo27hbzUst64lEY1VIoWVkkVUyb1pWPX5CcPYpbQV6Ay~MjUnDm2OKHb0n50P~AQ-jPnSrQ-lrpIDp9FkCE5ZmuFJlcAmYmole6tE9yAm4UEseC7odzgCtj51keQkCm21ixWEL240qp2HaDQ~oo4xgPFXPe~La~ehEF6iVKHpORIXX-9CCTTNrNJPk9rNS4bOK3byjouclZ7ORKThkcpu5fVmGmuQ8ryYECDGUrpjlJAhfg8pM83yuv7W3t4-dVDEnlPJTUeIDW0UFNc18E8zHMhjhHgjh9huyz1Uy6DewYsA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=111794113&ar=1747562&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig5.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">SEDs of the lens and of the background source for the five H-ATLAS/SDP gravitational lensing systems. The new photometric data points from <em>HST</em>/WFC3 are indicated by filled circles (cyan for the lens and orange for the background source) while other existing photometric data are represented with either error bars or downward arrows in case of upper limits. The optical data are from SDSS and Keck while measurements at near/mid-IR are from VIKING, <em>WISE</em>, and <em>Spitzer</em>. The sub-mm/millimetre photometry is from PACS/<em>Herschel</em>, SPIRE/<em>Herschel</em>, SMA and MAMBO/IRAM. Upper limits at PACS/<em>Herschel</em> wavelengths are shown at 3\u8201\u03c3. Data points are blue for the lens photometry, red for the background source photometry and black for the lens+source photometry. The best-fitting SED is in cyan for the lens and in orange for the source. The thick grey line is their sum. For SDP.9 and SDP.11 the lighter orange curve shows the best-fitting results for the lensed source when the <em>WISE</em> data points at 12 and 22| $\\,\\mu$ |m are included in the fit. For SDP.130, the dashed curve is the best-fitting SED obtained for the lensed source when the Keck upper limits are also taken into account.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/440/3/10.1093_mnras_stu413/3/m_stu413fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611467611&amp;Signature=YurkynRXsLWM2I2O7cYJJ08KF0W6gqmmoNx-ldIAERPcY8nYimmSWRH3f8K6RLz60b3djJF9JXtTliX0e4rILfrIneayNrM5PZNfCBxaMEhkXI~I6kI2L25Ntr9ImyafN0GFX~u0n-wxCl1p65pX35cVAbmilszWe6yE7RuuiAqsP--cU4hQCM0jeAjhKdOMzWddRHkOnCjQP65qBMp3mDT4tMGUSwQfOMwmgF5BridfjLTQdQEyjSgd3pmV2mBdtFEF-flIoTkzJygYWQqBmMBI7~yAYpNPCmPTsktrZA3wei7oY~5euyuVFIqdsh8DV59Aj0eHO0wYpw9ZjGTM-g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"SEDs of the lens and of the background source for the five H-ATLAS/SDP gravitational lensing systems. The new photometric data points from HST/WFC3 are indicated by filled circles (cyan for the lens and orange for the background source) while other existing photometric data are represented with either error bars or downward arrows in case of upper limits. The optical data are from SDSS and Keck while measurements at near/mid-IR are from VIKING, WISE, and Spitzer. The sub-mm/millimetre photometry is from PACS/Herschel, SPIRE/Herschel, SMA and MAMBO/IRAM. Upper limits at PACS/Herschel wavelengths are shown at 3\u8201\u03c3. Data points are blue for the lens photometry, red for the background source photometry and black for the lens+source photometry. The best-fitting SED is in cyan for the lens and in orange for the source. The thick grey line is their sum. For SDP.9 and SDP.11 the lighter orange curve shows the best-fitting results for the lensed source when the WISE data points at 12 and 22 $\\,\\mu$ m are included in the fit. For SDP.130, the dashed curve is the best-fitting SED obtained for the lensed source when the Keck upper limits are also taken into account.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig5.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/111794113/stu413fig5.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig5.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"111794113\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/440/3/10.1093_mnras_stu413/3/stu413fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611467611&Signature=5IKsiZo1zHCFhRBxkfD8-WKeNryIrWBZnWrkf3f9AIo27hbzUst64lEY1VIoWVkkVUyb1pWPX5CcPYpbQV6Ay~MjUnDm2OKHb0n50P~AQ-jPnSrQ-lrpIDp9FkCE5ZmuFJlcAmYmole6tE9yAm4UEseC7odzgCtj51keQkCm21ixWEL240qp2HaDQ~oo4xgPFXPe~La~ehEF6iVKHpORIXX-9CCTTNrNJPk9rNS4bOK3byjouclZ7ORKThkcpu5fVmGmuQ8ryYECDGUrpjlJAhfg8pM83yuv7W3t4-dVDEnlPJTUeIDW0UFNc18E8zHMhjhHgjh9huyz1Uy6DewYsA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=111794113&ar=1747562&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig5.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">SEDs of the lens and of the background source for the five H-ATLAS/SDP gravitational lensing systems. The new photometric data points from <em>HST</em>/WFC3 are indicated by filled circles (cyan for the lens and orange for the background source) while other existing photometric data are represented with either error bars or downward arrows in case of upper limits. The optical data are from SDSS and Keck while measurements at near/mid-IR are from VIKING, <em>WISE</em>, and <em>Spitzer</em>. The sub-mm/millimetre photometry is from PACS/<em>Herschel</em>, SPIRE/<em>Herschel</em>, SMA and MAMBO/IRAM. Upper limits at PACS/<em>Herschel</em> wavelengths are shown at 3\u8201\u03c3. Data points are blue for the lens photometry, red for the background source photometry and black for the lens+source photometry. The best-fitting SED is in cyan for the lens and in orange for the source. The thick grey line is their sum. For SDP.9 and SDP.11 the lighter orange curve shows the best-fitting results for the lensed source when the <em>WISE</em> data points at 12 and 22| $\\,\\mu$ |m are included in the fit. For SDP.130, the dashed curve is the best-fitting SED obtained for the lensed source when the Keck upper limits are also taken into account.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=111794114 id=\"111794114\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1>5.1 SED fitting with <span class=\"small-caps\">magphys</span></h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We fit the observed SEDs using the public code Multiwavelength Analysis of Galaxy Physical Properties (<span class=\"small-caps\">magphys</span>; da Cunha, Charlot &amp; Elbaz <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>), which exploits a large library of optical and IR templates linked together in a physically consistent way. The evolution of the dust-free stellar emission is computed using the population synthesis model of Bruzual &amp; Charlot (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>), by assuming a Chabrier (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) initial mass function (IMF) that is cutoff below 0.1 and above 100\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>; adopting a Salpeter IMF instead gives stellar masses that are a factor of \u223c1.8 larger.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The attenuation of starlight by dust is described by the two-component model of Charlot &amp; Fall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>), where dust is associated with the birth clouds and with the diffuse interstellar medium (ISM). Starlight is assumed to be the only significant heating source (i.e. any contribution from an active galactic nucleus is neglected). The dust emission at far-infrared to sub-mm/millimetre wavelengths is modelled as a two modified grey-body SED with dust emissivity index \u03b2\u00a0=\u00a01.5 for the warm dust (30\u201360\u00a0K) and \u03b2\u00a0=\u00a02 for the cold dust (15\u201330\u00a0K). The dust mass absorption coefficient, <em>k</em><sub>\u03bb</sub>\u00a0\u221d\u00a0\u03bb<sup>\u2212\u03b2</sup>, is approximated as a power law with normalization | $k_{\\rm 850\\mu m}=0.077$ |\u00a0m<sup>2</sup>\u00a0kg<sup>\u22121</sup> (Dunne et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Among the best SED-fit parameters provided by <span class=\"small-caps\">magphys</span> we report the following in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>: total (| $3\\hbox{--}1000\\,\\mu$ |m) IR luminosity of dust emission (<em>L</em><sub>dust</sub> or <em>L</em><sub>IR</sub>), star formation rate (averaged over the last 100\u00a0Myr), SFR, stellar mass, <em>M</em><sub>*</sub>, dust mass, <em>M</em><sub>dust</sub>, temperature of the warm dust component, | $T_{\\rm dust}^{\\rm (warm)}$ |, fraction of the IR luminosity due to the warm dust, | $\\xi _{\\rm dust}^{\\rm (warm)}=L_{\\rm dust}^{\\rm (warm)}/L_{\\rm dust}$ |. In order to derive the <em>intrinsic</em> properties of the background source, a correction for the amplification due to lensing is applied. We adopt the magnification factors derived by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D14</a> who have modelled the lens-subtracted <em>HST</em> images using a multiwavelength semilinear inversion technique (Warren &amp; Dye <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>). The method also provides constraints on the total mass density profile of the lens and on the distribution of the UV/rest-frame optical emission in the source plane. We neglect the effect of differential magnification, i.e. the dependence of the magnification factor on the observing wavelength (Serjeant <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). In fact, the amplification factors derived by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D14</a> are consistent with those derived for the same objects from the SMA images at 880| $\\,\\mu$ |m (Bussmann et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Thousands of simulated values for the <em>observed</em><span class=\"small-caps\">magphys</span> parameters are generated from the likelihood probability distributions provided by <span class=\"small-caps\">magphys</span> and then divided by the magnification factors randomly drawn from a Gaussian distribution with mean value and rms taken from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D14</a>. The medians of the simulated amplification-corrected values are taken as the best estimates of the <em>intrinsic</em> properties of the source and are those listed in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. The associated errors correspond to the confidence interval in the 16th to 84th percentile range. We also include in the table the estimates of the molecular gas mass, <em>M</em><sub>gas</sub>, which is information provided by Frayer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and Lupu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) via the detection of CO emission lines. We have updated their estimates in light of the new amplification factors derived by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D14</a>. We also derive the molecular gas fraction, <em>f</em><sub>gas</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0<em>M</em><sub>gas</sub>/(<em>M</em><sub>gas</sub> + <em>M</em><sub>star</sub>) and gas depletion time-scale, \u03c4<sub>gas</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0<em>M</em><sub>gas</sub>/SFR, both reported in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For the fit to the SED of the background source we adopt the SED templates calibrated to reproduce the ultraviolet-infrared SEDs of local, purely star-forming ULIRGs (da Cunha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), while we use dust-free SED templates to fit the SED of the lenses (i.e. pure Bruzual &amp; Charlot <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a> models). For the latter we just report the estimated mass in stars and star formation rate in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In general, we assume that the measured SDSS and VIKING photometry have contributions from both the foreground galaxy and the lensed source, unless otherwise stated. In fact, ground based observations are limited by the seeing, which makes it extremely difficult to separate the lens from the background source in our relatively compact targets. We further assume that the emission at 12 and 22| $\\,\\mu$ |m (as measured by <em>WISE</em>) is entirely contributed by the lensed source while the <em>WISE</em> photometry at 3.4 and 4.6| $\\,\\mu$ |m carries contributions from both the lens and the source, unless otherwise stated. The best-fitting SED models are shown Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>. Below we provide more details on the fit to the SED for each object individually.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>SDP.9</strong>. At wavelengths | $\\lambda \\lesssim 1\\,\\mu$ |m the emission is dominated by the foreground galaxy. The flux density ratio between the source and the lens increases from 0.08 to 0.2 going from 1.1\u00a0| $\\mu$ |m to 1.6\u00a0| $\\mu$ |m, so that we expect the <em>H</em> and <em>Ks</em> VIKING photometry to carry significant contributions from both the lens and the background source. Therefore, for the SED of the foreground galaxy we have adopted the SDSS and the <em>Z</em> + <em>Y</em> + <em>J</em> VIKING photometry, as well as the <em>HST</em> lens photometry. For the background source, we have fitted the corresponding <em>HST</em> photometry, together with 5\u8201\u03c3 upper limits from Keck in the optical (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">N10</a>) and all the available data at mid-IR (i.e. <em>WISE</em> W3+W4) to sub-mm/mm wavelengths, where the contribution from the lens is null. All the other photometric data are used as upper limits in the fit. The results are shown in the top-left panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a> and are found to be independent on the inclusion of the Keck upper limits. However we fail to reproduce the <em>WISE</em> data point at 12| $\\,\\mu$ |m (light orange curve). There is a clear excess at mid-IR wavelengths that may be due to emission from a dusty torus around an active galactic nucleus (AGN). The presence of a dust-obscured AGN in SDP.9 is also suggested by the analysis of Omont et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) on the H<sub>2</sub>O(2<sub>02</sub>1<sub>11</sub>)/CO(8-7) and <em>I</em>(H<sub>2</sub>O)/L<sub>FIR</sub> ratios. Our SED models do not include any AGN component, which may provide the dominant contribution to the continuum mid-IR emission. Therefore we assume as our best-fitting SED model the one derived by ignoring the <em>WISE</em> W3+W4 data points (thick orange curve). The effect of the AGN on the derived best-fitting <span class=\"small-caps\">magphys</span> parameters is discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.2</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">According to <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D14</a> the source is amplified by a factor \u03bc\u00a0=\u00a06.3 and consists of a dominant emitting region of \u223c1\u8201kpc in size, and a smaller and fainter one separated by a few kpc. The latter is responsible for the fainter structure observed in the Einstein ring. The background source has a mass in stars <em>M</em><sub>*</sub>\u00a0=\u00a07.1\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>10</sup>\u8201M<sub>\u2299</sub>, a comparable mass in molecular gas, <em>M</em><sub>gas</sub>\u00a0=\u00a03.4\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>10</sup>\u8201M<sub>\u2299</sub>, and form stars at a rate of 366\u8201M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u8201yr<sup>\u22121</sup>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>SDP.11</strong>. The foreground galaxy and the lensed source have about the same flux densities at near-IR wavelengths. This means that lower spatial resolution near-IR photometric data, as those provided by the VIKING survey, may carry similar contributions from the lens and the background source, although the two are completely blended together. Based on the available upper limits at optical wavelengths for the lensed source we decided to use the <em>u</em> + <em>g</em> + <em>r</em> + <em>i</em> SDSS photometry as well as the <em>HST</em> lens photometry to describe the SED of the foreground galaxy, while the fit to the SED of the lensed galaxy is performed on the <em>Keck</em> upper limits, the <em>HST</em> source photometry and on photometric data at wavelengths | $&gt;10\\,\\mu$ |m. However, also in this case we fail to reproduce the <em>WISE</em> W3 data point (light orange curve). We conclude that a significant fraction of the mid-IR emission in SDP.11 may come from an AGN (see discussion in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.2</a>). As for SDP.9, we assume as our best-fitting SED model the one derived by ignoring the <em>WISE</em> W3+W4 data points (thick orange curve).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The magnification factor derived by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D14</a> for the background galaxy is \u03bc\u00a0=\u00a07.9. The reconstructed source comprises several knots of rest-frame optical emission, distributed within a region of a few kpc, which are responsible for the small-scale structure observed in the Einstein ring (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D14</a>). Compared to SDP.9, the source has a higher star formation rate, SFR\u00a0\u223c\u00a0650\u8201M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u8201yr<sup>\u22121</sup>, a higher mass in stars <em>M</em><sub>*</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.9\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>11</sup>\u8201M<sub>\u2299</sub>, and a lower gas fraction, <em>f</em><sub>gas</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.14.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>SDP.17</strong>. This case is similar to that of SDP.11 with the foreground galaxy and the lensed source having very similar flux densities at near-IR wavelengths. Therefore we fit the SED of the lens including just the <em>HST</em> lens photometry and adopting the SDSS data points as upper limits. We fit similarly for the lensed source with the addition of the photometric data at wavelengths longwards of 10| $\\,\\mu$ |m. No indication of a mid-IR \u2018excess\u2019 is found in this case.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The background galaxy is affected by a small amplification, \u03bc\u00a0=\u00a03.6 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D14</a>). Given its relatively high redshift and high | $500\\,\\mu$ |m flux density, the source is the brightest among the lensed galaxies in the sample, with an infrared luminosity exceeding | $10^{13}\\,\\text{L}_{{\\odot }}$ |. There are two distinct objects in the source plane, each one of 2\u20133\u00a0kpc in size, and separated by a few kpc (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D14</a>). This morphology may be indicative of an on-going merger. The background system has SFR\u00a0\u223c\u00a02300\u8201M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u8201yr<sup>\u22121</sup> and <em>M</em><sub>*</sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.4\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>11</sup>\u8201M<sub>\u2299</sub>. The mass in molecular gas is <em>M</em><sub>gas</sub>\u00a0=\u00a05.9\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>10</sup>\u8201M<sub>\u2299</sub>, corresponding to a gas fraction of 20 per cent.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>SDP.81</strong>. The foreground galaxy completely dominates the emission at wavelengths shorter than a few\u00a0| $\\mu$ |m. Therefore the fit to the SED of the lens is done on the SDSS and VIKING data, as well as on the lens photometry from <em>HST</em> and <em>Spitzer</em> (Hopwood et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). As for the background galaxy, we fit upper limits from Keck, source photometry from <em>HST</em> and <em>Spitzer</em> and all the other available photometric data above 10| $\\,\\mu$ |m.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The background galaxy is amplified by a factor \u03bc\u00a0=\u00a011, the highest among those derived by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D14</a>. The lensed system resembles a classic cusp-caustic configuration and the reconstructed source shows little structure other than a slight elongation. The background galaxy has SFR\u00a0=\u00a0527\u8201M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u8201yr<sup>\u22121</sup> and <em>M</em><sub>*</sub>\u00a0=\u00a03.3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>10</sup>\u8201M<sub>\u2299</sub>, with a gas fraction of 33 per cent.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>SDP.130</strong>. The lensed galaxy is an order of magnitude fainter than the foreground galaxy at 1.1 and 1.6| $\\,\\mu$ |m. On the other hand the complicated morphology of the foreground galaxy may suggest that the upper limits available at optical wavelengths for the lensed source are poorly constrained. In fact, we failed to reproduce simultaneously those limits and the <em>HST</em> photometry (dashed curve), as the increase in flux density from 0.7 to 1.1| $\\,\\mu$ |m is too steep. Therefore we also show in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a> the best-fitting SED model derived when the Keck upper limits are not included in the fit (thick orange curve). The latter is assumed as our best-fitting SED model for the background galaxy.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As for SDP.17, the amplification is relatively small, \u03bc\u00a0=\u00a03.1 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D14</a>). The source extends over several kpc and there is a hint of substructures (two main knots of emission) from the reconstructed F160W image (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D14</a>). The background galaxy has infrared luminosity close to | $10^{13}\\,\\text{L}_{{\\odot }}$ | and <em>SFR</em>\u00a0=\u00a01026\u8201M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u8201yr<sup>\u22121</sup>. The mass in stars exceeds 10<sup>11</sup>\u8201M<sub>\u2299</sub>, while that in molecular gas is 5.3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>10</sup>\u8201M<sub>\u2299</sub>, corresponding to a gas fraction of 28 per cent.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=111794130 id=\"111794130\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2>5.2 Effect of the AGN on the estimated <span class=\"small-caps\">magphys</span> parameters</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The \u2018excess\u2019 emission at mid-IR wavelengths observed in SDP.9 and SDP.11 suggests the presence of a buried AGN, which may have an impact on the <span class=\"small-caps\">magphys</span> results presented in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. A way to investigate this effect is to fit the observed SED with a combination of AGN and star-forming templates (e.g. Negrello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Berta et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Delvecchio et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). However this approach may lead to large degeneracies between model parameters when the spectral coverage is not sufficiently good, as it is the case here. In fact, only few constraints on the SED of the background galaxy are available at optical and near-IR wavelengths. For this reason we have adopted a simpler approach. We have assumed that the mid-infrared emission is completely dominated by the AGN and fitted the <em>WISE</em> W3 and W4 photometry with a suitable set of AGN templates. The photometric data points at optical/near-IR/far-IR/sub-mm/mm wavelengths are taken as upper limits in the fitting process. We have exploited the library<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn5\" data-open=\"fn5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>4</sup></a> of AGN templates provided by Fritz, Franceschini &amp; Hatziminaoglou (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), and further expanded by Feltre et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). The AGN library includes 2400 templates, obtained by varying the torus opening angle, the radial and the height slope of the torus density profile, the equatorial optical depth at 9.7\u00a0| $\\mu$ |m, the ratio between the outer and inner radius of the dust distribution and the viewing angle of the line of sight. Once the best-fitting AGN template is found, the latter is subtracted from the observed SED and the residuals are fitted again with <span class=\"small-caps\">magphys</span>. Where the residuals are consistent with zero (i.e. in the W3 and W4 bands) 3\u8201\u03c3 upper limits are assumed, \u03c3 being the error on the measured photometry at that wavelength. The new SED fit results are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>. In general, the contribution of the AGN is confined to the mid-IR spectral region, although in SDP.9 it also extends to near-IR wavelengths where the AGN accounts for about 20 per cent of the measured flux density at 1.6\u00a0| $\\mu$ |m. The overall effect on the newly derived <span class=\"small-caps\">magphys</span> parameters is to decrease the infrared luminosities and the star formation rates (as well as the mass in stars for SDP.9) compared to the values quoted in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. However, as expected, the differences are not significant (i.e. well within the 1\u03c3 uncertainties). In fact the measured <em>WISE</em> W3 and W4 photometry was significantly underestimated by the best-fitting <span class=\"small-caps\">magphys</span> template even before the AGN component was included in the fit.</p>                        <a id=\"111794132\" scrollto-destination=\"111794132\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/440/3/10.1093_mnras_stu413/3/m_stu413fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611467611&amp;Signature=Bbd-vBVMjXTEzcqXFYRKlwVLzm5yjqYajnjY2vhVqwi9vEsmP2MR2GRBPCXa4vuJ9HH0h03oBcdc-kcd4xwhWlk8JEtLoXkhn~ggH9yYkj9lbVU5YIQ2HtuM2l0apDITJ0AsUbh3MvClDtd6lVV6DGPiIMkUyEZlTL0MY9EhK92D04Jr2sfshQi-p7S93Jy-z7zWXB742t5omvSbW7gCw33dF8131e6vZY9oAqeZbWwGIySYX42bjBexymDG~a9UsTJOBTRPfGdckGsLx0~f-cSpXEi~Gf6WjCX9MAQ3zHejANEZr3MSfmwz1nJuOxnhxYW779oeKIgdzWy10pBX6A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Same as in Fig.\u00a05 for SDP.9 and SDP.11 but with the inclusion of an AGN component, represented by the green curve. The orange curve is the sum of the star-forming and the AGN components.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig6.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/111794132/stu413fig6.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig6.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"111794132\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/440/3/10.1093_mnras_stu413/3/stu413fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611467611&Signature=E8CKEYLG9uvP1627OQQCg0aSEiF5-zDbWmaRQwOVOW-p7jXupPbI2eYRbgCpOvKMuJJtKo8pBshBqy2SkaRJdf~6Y6dbvOfkPbA23h6~mr98g4N1ZIyjHhO~xzq2NrkNRXcJzF5qiu9xwSvcBXeD2lJ-hEN1JvVLRGe4Y-cw-YxySMep4lBpkhZz88YGqVH2v2RuQi9cs0TjOHDk32Bi8bpfVQhBw1FJPjfMgD6oGYKpNZHZsyRAkpxqaD8avQ8p0Wvv48V~w81FwAIKCEA2O7Ue6RwQDZCaNFjHlRZxUjT~ceaZoRS~Rheb1-SbQZVjZtlhD4NUqMBKcbkq-2l35g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=111794132&ar=1747562&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig6.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Same as in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a> for SDP.9 and SDP.11 but with the inclusion of an AGN component, represented by the green curve. The star-forming component, as derived from <span class=\"small-caps\">MAGPHYS</span>, is shown in yellow. The orange curve is the sum of the star-forming and the AGN components.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/440/3/10.1093_mnras_stu413/3/m_stu413fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611467611&amp;Signature=Bbd-vBVMjXTEzcqXFYRKlwVLzm5yjqYajnjY2vhVqwi9vEsmP2MR2GRBPCXa4vuJ9HH0h03oBcdc-kcd4xwhWlk8JEtLoXkhn~ggH9yYkj9lbVU5YIQ2HtuM2l0apDITJ0AsUbh3MvClDtd6lVV6DGPiIMkUyEZlTL0MY9EhK92D04Jr2sfshQi-p7S93Jy-z7zWXB742t5omvSbW7gCw33dF8131e6vZY9oAqeZbWwGIySYX42bjBexymDG~a9UsTJOBTRPfGdckGsLx0~f-cSpXEi~Gf6WjCX9MAQ3zHejANEZr3MSfmwz1nJuOxnhxYW779oeKIgdzWy10pBX6A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Same as in Fig.\u00a05 for SDP.9 and SDP.11 but with the inclusion of an AGN component, represented by the green curve. The star-forming component, as derived from MAGPHYS, is shown in yellow. The orange curve is the sum of the star-forming and the AGN components.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig6.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/111794132/stu413fig6.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig6.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"111794132\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/440/3/10.1093_mnras_stu413/3/stu413fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611467611&Signature=E8CKEYLG9uvP1627OQQCg0aSEiF5-zDbWmaRQwOVOW-p7jXupPbI2eYRbgCpOvKMuJJtKo8pBshBqy2SkaRJdf~6Y6dbvOfkPbA23h6~mr98g4N1ZIyjHhO~xzq2NrkNRXcJzF5qiu9xwSvcBXeD2lJ-hEN1JvVLRGe4Y-cw-YxySMep4lBpkhZz88YGqVH2v2RuQi9cs0TjOHDk32Bi8bpfVQhBw1FJPjfMgD6oGYKpNZHZsyRAkpxqaD8avQ8p0Wvv48V~w81FwAIKCEA2O7Ue6RwQDZCaNFjHlRZxUjT~ceaZoRS~Rheb1-SbQZVjZtlhD4NUqMBKcbkq-2l35g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=111794132&ar=1747562&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig6.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Same as in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a> for SDP.9 and SDP.11 but with the inclusion of an AGN component, represented by the green curve. The star-forming component, as derived from <span class=\"small-caps\">MAGPHYS</span>, is shown in yellow. The orange curve is the sum of the star-forming and the AGN components.</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=111794133 id=\"111794133\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>6 DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">All the galaxies in the sample are classified as Ultra Luminous Infrared Galaxies (ULIRGs; 10<sup>12</sup>\u8201L<sub>\u2299</sub> \u2264 <em>L</em><sub>IR</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a010<sup>13</sup>\u8201L<sub>\u2299</sub>) with the exception of SDP.17; its infrared luminosity, <em>L</em><sub>IR</sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>13</sup>\u8201L<sub>\u2299</sub>, makes it a Hyper Luminous Infrared Galaxy (HyLIRGs). SDP.17 is not the first example of HyLIRG discovered among the H-ATLAS lens candidates. Other examples are the | $z$ |\u00a0=\u00a04.243 lensed galaxy analysed by Cox et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and further investigated by Bussmann et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), the | $z$ |\u00a0=\u00a03.259 source lensed by a galaxy group discussed in Fu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), and the two star-bursting galaxies (one of which is weakly lensed) at | $z$ |\u00a0=\u00a02.41 presented by Ivison et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). A few more examples have been found in the <em>Herschel</em> Multi-tiered Extragalactic Survey(HerMES; Oliver <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>): a | $z$ |\u00a0=\u00a02.9575 source lensed by a galaxy group (Conley et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and a weakly lensed merging system at | $z$ |\u00a0=\u00a02.308 (Fu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The inferred star formation rates are in the range \u2273400\u20132000\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u00a0yr<sup>\u22121</sup>, reaching a maximum for SDP.17 and SDP.130. The derived dust masses, <em>M</em><sub>dust</sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a0(7\u201330)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>8</sup>\u8201M<sub>\u2299</sub> and dust temperatures, <em>T</em>\u00a0=\u00a037\u201347\u8201K, are in agreement with what is commonly found for high-redshift ULIRGs/HyLIRGs (Micha\u0142owski, Hjorth &amp; Watson <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Bussmann et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). At these high rates of star formation, the mass in stars grows very rapidly as the available molecular gas is quickly exhausted. With the aid of the new <em>HST</em> photometry we estimate that a mass of \u223c(7\u201320)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>10</sup>\u8201M<sub>\u2299</sub> is already locked up in stars. Although high, these values are a factor of \u00d74 lower than those derived by Hopwood et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) for SDP.81 and SDP.130. In fact, their SED fitting could only rely on upper limits for the flux density of the lensed source at wavelengths | $\\lambda &lt;3.6\\,\\mu$ |m. Our estimates of the mass in stars are consistent with those derived for other sub-millimetre selected galaxies (Micha\u0142owski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Hainline et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Yun et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>, see also Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"111794136\" scrollto-destination=\"111794136\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/440/3/10.1093_mnras_stu413/3/m_stu413fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611467611&amp;Signature=yoor6x-fW-HrICJeRGyvek04WnK79vHglrDrWd7WS36VszYHwkLmBLmpmkrTqgevQnbYGchWdrf5cjYx8-T~iGJvxpgnzB7eYh0vu770839NTqFc783b49MBSh1Tm8GtV80cc9lkf0AvLxHoYVOmHXBssXPa0qLj-3d1Pwy7v0dplTYx8Eug28Tq4L7f0Cstunrq0pS4aARMznVrRRNmchH5KW9dsrvk8GFdyyk3ABXrQhOEU2DpWq0RaJRQzmC7FaDi0gEivcWnanGogW76wizRT5Q1hvZyRBJjrmVCj-Drm54hzXqw~o~52z6UY6TCXk5uvkxQZNJ4enWLof2Hdw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Infrared luminosity, mass in stars, mass in molecular gas and gas fraction of the five H-ATLAS/SDP lensed galaxies (black dots) compared with other sub-mm selected lensed/un-lensed galaxies from literature: Ivison et\u00a0al. (2010; their values of <em>M</em><sub>*</sub> have been rescaled by a factor of 1.8 to convert from Salpeter to Chabrier initial mass function.)</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/440/3/10.1093_mnras_stu413/3/m_stu413fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611467611&amp;Signature=yoor6x-fW-HrICJeRGyvek04WnK79vHglrDrWd7WS36VszYHwkLmBLmpmkrTqgevQnbYGchWdrf5cjYx8-T~iGJvxpgnzB7eYh0vu770839NTqFc783b49MBSh1Tm8GtV80cc9lkf0AvLxHoYVOmHXBssXPa0qLj-3d1Pwy7v0dplTYx8Eug28Tq4L7f0Cstunrq0pS4aARMznVrRRNmchH5KW9dsrvk8GFdyyk3ABXrQhOEU2DpWq0RaJRQzmC7FaDi0gEivcWnanGogW76wizRT5Q1hvZyRBJjrmVCj-Drm54hzXqw~o~52z6UY6TCXk5uvkxQZNJ4enWLof2Hdw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Infrared luminosity, mass in stars, mass in molecular gas and gas fraction of the five H-ATLAS/SDP lensed galaxies (black dots) compared with other sub-mm selected lensed/un-lensed galaxies from literature: Ivison et\u00a0al. (2013; cyan), Fu et\u00a0al. (2012; green), Conley et\u00a0al. (2011; red), Fu et\u00a0al. (2013; purple). The shaded grey region corresponds to the 16th to 84th percentile range of the distribution of values derived for the sample of sub-millimetre galaxies with CO line measurements compiled by Bothwell et\u00a0al. (2013; with mass in stars taken from Hainline et\u00a0al. 2011). The shaded yellow region shows the infrared luminosities and masses in stars estimated by Micha\u0142lowski et\u00a0al. (2010; their values of M* have been rescaled by a factor of 1.8 to convert from Salpeter to Chabrier initial mass function.)\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig7.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/111794136/stu413fig7.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig7.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"111794136\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/440/3/10.1093_mnras_stu413/3/stu413fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611467611&Signature=oKKBrLdXmells6AM8Em2tttarVYvzapmZ5yTqxi35K8uJ24vuOewzrMrjaWramaFOfV2oVpFUvwPT9aG74rN~Cd2Z7s8Ctywt5iSrniUsjYe4yoHFPru~F94fAG~I0-qPiBJymdPUgVmPKeoXXgvhDDF3azjfAI1AqHUccDTVvvwRnLbahsiAsQIO1KnViftZ4F-KzQZT5FlrF4DyCrSCHdneRM-mSkiCFRDsm4ypIJlR3COt2pzlXWTkXf6qzQoqyOQsemQrq7V4X3tjxRJCfmWnvqr6mKEjDs-6mCEURRfODFCPbKLUZ326XH1SPqTBtb6W03VqHaBcDeecwQUGw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=111794136&ar=1747562&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu413fig7.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Infrared luminosity, mass in stars, mass in molecular gas and gas fraction of the five H-ATLAS/SDP lensed galaxies (black dots) compared with other sub-mm selected lensed/un-lensed galaxies from literature: Ivison et\u00a0al. (2013; cyan), Fu et\u00a0al. (2012; green), Conley et\u00a0al. (2011; red), Fu et\u00a0al. (2013; purple). The shaded grey region corresponds to the 16th to 84th percentile range of the distribution of values derived for the sample of sub-millimetre galaxies with CO line measurements compiled by Bothwell et\u00a0al. (2013; with mass in stars taken from Hainline et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). The shaded yellow region shows the infrared luminosities and masses in stars estimated by Micha\u0142lowski et\u00a0al. (2010; their values of <em>M</em><sub>*</sub> have been rescaled by a factor of 1.8 to convert from Salpeter to Chabrier initial mass function.)</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">For how long will these galaxies continue to form stars? This depends on the mass of molecular gas, <em>M</em><sub>gas</sub>, still available in these sources. We find large reservoir of molecular gas, <em>M</em><sub>gas</sub>\u00a0&gt;\u00a03\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>10</sup>\u8201M<sub>\u2299</sub>, consistently with what is observed in other sub-millimetre galaxies (Bothwell et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>, in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>). If star formation is sustained at the rate estimated here, the gas will be exhausted in less than 100\u00a0Myr (\u00d72 longer if gas recycling is accounted for in stellar evolution; Fu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). By the end of this intense episode of star formation such galaxies will have assembled a mass in stars of (1\u20133)\u00a0\u00d7 10<sup>11</sup>\u8201M<sub>\u2299</sub>. Unless further gas is accreted from the surrounding environment or through minor/major mergers, they will passively evolve into massive ellipticals at the present time. These galaxies are thus proto-ellipticals caught during their major episode of star formation.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Evidence for the presence of an AGN have been found in two sources (SDP.9 and SDP.11). The inferred AGN bolometric luminosities (corrected for lensing) are 1.3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>12</sup>\u8201L<sub>\u2299</sub> for SDP.9 and 1.1\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>13</sup>\u8201L<sub>\u2299</sub> for SDP.11, although these may be overestimated. In fact, due to the smaller size of the emitting region, the <em>apparent</em> AGN luminosity is probably affected by a higher magnification than that derived from imaging data at near-IR and sub-mm wavelengths. The emerging of an AGN is expected during the final stage of the evolution of massive forming spheroids at | $z$ |\u00a0\u2273 1.5 as a mechanism to quench the star formation and to account for the <em>cosmic downsizing</em> (see e.g. Granato et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>, and references therein). In their recently proposed model for the co-evolution of supermassive black holes and their host galaxies, Lapi et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) have shown that the ratio <em>L</em><sub>FIR</sub>/<em>L</em><sub>AGN</sub> between the far-infrared luminosity (i.e. luminosity integrated in the rest-frame wavelength range 40\u00a0| $\\mu$ |m\u2013500\u00a0| $\\mu$ |m) and the AGN bolometric luminosity characterizes the time evolution of the galaxy plus AGN system; it is a decreasing function of the galactic time and marks the evolution from the epoch when the luminosity budget is dominated by the star formation (<em>L</em><sub>FIR</sub>/<em>L</em><sub>AGN</sub>\u00a0&gt;\u00a01) to the epoch when the AGN/QSO takes over (<em>L</em><sub>FIR</sub>/<em>L</em><sub>AGN</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a01). This ratio is \u223c4 for SDP.9 and \u223c0.5 for SDP.11, suggesting that in the former the central black hole is still in his early phase of mass accretion, while in the latter the black hole has reached its final mass and the AGN feedback is about to quench the star formation and to stop the inflow of gas towards the centre of the galaxy. According to Lapi et\u00a0al. the central black hole grows exponentially from a seed of \u227210<sup>4</sup>\u8201M<sub>\u2299</sub>, with a luminosity close to (or slightly above) the Eddington luminosity. The e-folding time-scale of the black hole growth is \u223c70\u8201Myr, assuming a mass to radiation conversion efficiency \u03f5\u00a0=\u00a00.15. Therefore, it would take about 8 (for SDP.9) to 12 (for SDP.11) e-folding times (i.e. \u223c550\u2212850\u00a0Myr) for the AGN to reach the observed bolometric luminosity starting from <em>M</em><sub>BH</sub>\u00a0=\u00a010<sup>4</sup>\u8201M<sub>\u2299</sub>. This value is consistent, within the (large) uncertainties, with the age of the sources derived from the measured mass in stars and SFR (assuming the SFR is kept constant during the starburst event), i.e.: | $M_{\\star }/\\rm{SFR}=467_{-371}^{+492}$ |\u00a0Myr for SDP.9 and | $M_{\\star }/\\rm{SFR}=382_{-141}^{+597 }$ |\u00a0Myr for SDP.11.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=111794139 id=\"111794139\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7>7 CONCLUSIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have presented deep <em>HST</em>/WFC3 F110W+F160W follow-up observations of the first gravitational lensing systems discovered by H-ATLAS in the SDP. The exquisite angular resolution of the <em>HST</em> images has allowed us to resolve an Einstein ring in two of these systems, and to identify multiple images in the others after a careful removal of the foreground galaxy. The lens-subtracted images have been used to model the rest-frame UV/optical emission in the source plane (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D14</a>) and to improve the constraints on the mass in stars and on other physical properties of lensed galaxies via SED fitting. Our conclusions can be summarized as follows: <ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The background sources comprise a mixture of ULIRGs and HyLIRG with star formation rates SFR\u00a0\u223c\u00a0400\u20132000\u8201M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u00a0yr<sup>\u22121</sup>, and large dust masses, <em>M</em><sub>dust</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0(7\u00a0\u2212\u00a030)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>8</sup>\u8201M<sub>\u2299</sub>. SDP.11 and SDP.17 are resolved into multiple knots of rest-frame UV/optical emission in the source plane (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D14</a>) indicative of either a major merger (Fu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) or distinct clumps of star formation within the same proto-galaxy (Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>).</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The lensed galaxies have already assembled a mass in stars <em>M</em><sub>*</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0(6\u201325)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>10</sup>\u8201M<sub>\u2299</sub>. Their molecular gas content is still significant, <em>f</em><sub>gas</sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a015\u201330 per cent, so that star formation can be sustained for another \u2272100\u8201Myr at the inferred rate.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">By the end of their star formation activity all these galaxies will have a mass in stars \u227310<sup>11</sup>\u8201M<sub>\u2299</sub>. We are thus witnessing the\u00a0very early stages in the formation of elliptical galaxies, during the peak epoch (| $z$ |\u00a0\u223c\u00a01.5\u20133) of the cosmic star formation history of the Universe.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">There is indication of the presence of an AGN in two of the lensed systems. The observed emission at mid-infrared wavelengths, in excess to that expected from purely star-forming SEDs, is a signature of the growth of the central black hole in these proto-ellipticals, as predicted by models for the co-evolution of supermassive black holes and their host galaxies (e.g. Lapi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>, and references therein).</p></li></ul></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The wide range of lens-to-source flux density ratios at 1.1- and 1.6-| $\\mu$ |m observed in this sample suggests that, in some cases, the lensed source may significantly contribute to the near-IR photometry of the system, as measured in low angular resolution VIKING and <em>WISE</em> surveys. Therefore, sub-mm lens candidates showing an \u2018excess\u2019 of emission at near-IR wavelengths compared to that expected for a passively evolving elliptical (i.e. the lens) are ideal targets for successful follow-up observations in the near-IR with <em>HST</em>/WFC3 and with the Keck telescopes (in Adaptive Optics), aiming at spatially resolving the lensed structure in these systems (Gonzalez-Nuevo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Many more lens candidates from both H-ATLAS and HerMES have been now observed with <em>HST</em>/WFC3/F110W in cycle-19 (PID: 12488) and with Keck/AO in the <em>H</em> and <em>K</em> bands. Lens modelling and SED fitting for these targets will be presented in a series of upcoming papers (Amber et\u00a0al., in preparation; Calanog et\u00a0al., in preparation).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This work was supported by STFC (grants PP/D002400/1 and ST/G002533/1), by ASI/INAF agreement I/072/09/0, by PRIN-INAF 2012 project \u2018Looking into the dust-obscured phase of galaxy formation through cosmic zoom lenses in the Herschel Astrophysical Large Area Survey\u2019 and, in part, by the Spanish Ministerio de Ciencia e Innovacion (project AYA2010-21766-C03-01). JGN acknowledges financial support from the Spanish CSIC for a JAE-DOC fellowship, co-funded by the European Social Fund. <em>Herschel</em> is an ESA space observatory with science instruments provided by European-led Principal Investigator consortia and with important participation from NASA. The <em>Herschel</em>-ATLAS is a project with <em>Herschel</em>, which is an ESA space observatory with science instruments provided by European-led Principal Investigator consortia and with important participation from NASA. The H-ATLAS website is <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.h-atlas.org/\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.h-atlas.org/</a>. This publication makes use of data products from the <em>WISE</em>, which is a joint project of the University of California, Los Angeles, and the Jet Propulsion Laboratory/California Institute of Technology, funded by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.</p><div content-id=\"fn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" class=\"end-note-link\">*</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><em>Herschel</em> is an ESA space observatory with science instruments provided by European-led Principal Investigator consortia and with important participation from NASA.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn2\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn2\" class=\"end-note-link\">1</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.h-atlas.org\" target=\"_blank\">www.h-atlas.org</a></p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn3\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn3\" class=\"end-note-link\">2</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">A cycle-19 <em>HST</em>/WFC3/F110W snapshot program has provided imaging data for \u2273100 lens candidates identified in <em>H</em>-ATLAS (PID: 12488; PI: Negrello).</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn4\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn4\" class=\"end-note-link\">3</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">The <em>w?mpro</em> photometry in the Wise All Sky Data Release catalogue, with ? equal to 1, 2, 3 or 4 depending on the observing band.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn5\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn5\" class=\"end-note-link\">4</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">The templates are publicly available and can be downloaded from <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://users.ugent.be/~jfritz/jfhp/TORUS.html\" target=\"_blank\">http://users.ugent.be/\u223cjfritz/jfhp/TORUS.html</a></p></div></span></div> class=\"volume\">756</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">134</div>.\r\n</p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1088%2F0004-637X%2F756%2F2%2F134\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"bib7\" data-legacy-id=\"bib7\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib7\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib7\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib7\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\">\r\n<span class=\"name string-name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">Bussmann</div>\r\n <div class=\"given-names\">S</div>\r\n</span>\r\n</span>. et al.,\r\n<div class=\"source \">ApJ</div>., <div class=\"year\">2013</div>, <div class=\"volume\">779</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">25</div>.\r\n</p></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"bib8\" data-legacy-id=\"bib8\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a src=\"//ouptag.scholarlyiq.com/ntpagetag.gif?js=0\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" border=\"0\" hspace=\"0\" vspace=\"0\" alt=\"Scholarly IQ\" />\r\n    </noscript>\r\n\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"ad-banner js-ad-riser ad-banner-riser\">\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-AdBlock widget-instance-RiserAd\">\n         \n    </div>\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n\r\n</body>\r\n</html>\r\n\r\n", "ADS link": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2014MNRAS.440.1999N", "Tables status": "Complete", "Inspection status": "Incomplete", "Paper Overview": {"abstract": "We report on deep near-infrared observations obtained with the Wide Field Camera-3 (WFC3) onboard the Hubble Space Telescope (HST) of the first five confirmed gravitational lensing events discovered by the Herschel Astrophysical Terahertz Large Area Survey (H-ATLAS). We succeed in disentangling the background galaxy from the lens to gain separate photometry of the two components. The HST data allow us to significantly improve on previous constraints of the mass in stars of the lensed galaxy and to perform accurate lens modelling of these systems, as described in the accompanying paper by Dye et al. We fit the spectral energy distributions of the background sources from near-IR to millimetre wavelengths and use the magnification factors estimated by Dye et al. to derive the intrinsic properties of the lensed galaxies. We find these galaxies to have star-formations rates (SFR) \u223c 400-2000 M<SUB>\u2609</SUB> yr<SUP>-1</SUP>, with \u223c(6-25) \u00d7 10<SUP>10</SUP> M<SUB>\u2609</SUB> of their baryonic mass already turned into stars. At these rates of star formation, all remaining molecular gas will be exhausted in less than \u223c100 Myr, reaching a final mass in stars of a few 10<SUP>11</SUP> M<SUB>\u2609</SUB>. These galaxies are thus proto-ellipticals caught during their major episode of star formation, and observed at the peak epoch (z \u223c 1.5-3) of the cosmic star formation history of the Universe.", "start_page": "1999", "authors": ["Negrello, M.", "Hopwood, R.", "Dye, S.", "da Cunha, E.", "Serjeant, S.", "Fritz, J.", "Rowlands, K.", "Fleuren, S.", "Bussmann, R. S.", "Cooray, A.", "Dannerbauer, H.", "Gonzalez-Nuevo, J.", "Lapi, A.", "Omont, A.", "Amber, S.", "Auld, R.", "Baes, M.", "Buttiglione, S.", "Cava, A.", "Danese, L.", "Dariush, A.", "De Zotti, G.", "Dunne, L.", "Eales, S.", "Ibar, E.", "Ivison, R. J.", "Kim, S.", "Leeuw, L.", "Maddox, S.", "Micha\u0142owski, M. J.", "Massardi, M.", "Pascale, E.", "Pohlen, M.", "Rigby, E.", "Smith, D. J. B.", "Sutherland, W.", "Temi, P.", "Wardlow, J."], "issn": "0035-8711", "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:1311.5898", "Title": "Herschel *-ATLAS: deep HST/WFC3 imaging of strongly lensed submillimetre galaxies", "type_of_reference": "JOUR", "keywords": ["gravitational lensing: strong", "galaxies: elliptical and lenticular", "cD", "galaxies: evolution", "galaxies: formation", "infrared: galaxies", "submillimetre: galaxies", "Astrophysics - Cosmology and Extragalactic Astrophysics"], "volume": "440", "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2014MNRAS.440.1999N", "end_page": "2012", "number": "3", "publication_year": "2014/05/1", "doi": "10.1093/mnras/stu413", "journal_name": "Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society", "author_address": ["AA(INAF, Osservatorio Astronomico di Padova, Vicolo Osservatorio 5, I-35122 Padova, Italy), AB(Imperial College London, Blackett Laboratory, Prince Consort Road, London SW7 2AZ, UK), AC(School of Physics and Astronomy, University of Nottingham, University Park, Nottingham NG7 2RD, UK), AD(Max Planck Institute for Astronomy, Koenigstuhl 17, D-69117 Heidelberg, Germany), AE(Department of Physical Sciences, The Open University, Walton Hall, Milton Keynes MK7 6AA, UK), AF(Sterrenkundig Observatorium, Universiteit Gent, Krijgslaan 281 S9, B-9000 Gent, Belgium), AG((SUPA) School of Physics &amp; Astronomy, University of St Andrews, North Haugh, St Andrews, KY16 9SS, UK), AH(School of Mathematical Sciences, Queen Mary, University of London, Mile End Road, London E1 4NS, UK), AI(Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, 60 Garden Street, Cambridge, MA 02138, USA; Department of Astronomy, Space Science Building, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853-6801, USA), AJ(Department of Physics &amp; Astronomy, University of California, Irvine, CA 92697, USA), AK(Institut fur Astronomie, Universitat Wien, Turkenschanzstrae 17, A-1160 Wien, Austria), AL(Instituto de Fisica de Cantabria (CSIC-UC), Avda. los Castros s/n, E-39005 Santander, Spain), AM(Dipartimento di Fisica, Universita' Tor Vergata, Via della Ricerca Scientifica 1, I-00133 Roma, Italy; Astrophysics Sector, SISSA, Via Bonomea 265, I-34136 Trieste, Italy), AN(UPMC Univ. Paris 06, UMR7095, Institut d'Astrophysique de Paris, 75014 Paris, France; CNRS, UMR7095, Institut d'Astrophysique de Paris, F-75014 Paris, France), AO(Department of Physical Sciences, The Open University, Walton Hall, Milton Keynes MK7 6AA, UK), AP(School of Physics and Astronomy, Cardiff University, The Parade, Cardiff CF24 3AA, UK), AQ(Sterrenkundig Observatorium, Universiteit Gent, Krijgslaan 281 S9, B-9000 Gent, Belgium), AR(INAF, Osservatorio Astronomico di Padova, Vicolo Osservatorio 5, I-35122 Padova, Italy), AS(Observatoire de Gen\u00e8ve, Universit\u00e9 de Gen\u00e8ve, 51 Ch. des Maillettes, CH-1290 Versoix, Switzerland), AT(Astrophysics Sector, SISSA, Via Bonomea 265, I-34136 Trieste, Italy), AU(School of Physics and Astronomy, Cardiff University, The Parade, Cardiff CF24 3AA, UK), AV(INAF, Osservatorio Astronomico di Padova, Vicolo Osservatorio 5, I-35122 Padova, Italy; Astrophysics Sector, SISSA, Via Bonomea 265, I-34136 Trieste, Italy), AW(Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Canterbury, Private Bag 4800, Christchurch, New Zealand), AX(School of Physics and Astronomy, Cardiff University, The Parade, Cardiff CF24 3AA, UK), AY(Instituto de F\u00edsica y Astronom\u00eda, Universidad de Valpara\u00edso, Avda.
